GRANT AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Kingdom of Bhutan 
 
Support  to  the  Government  of  Bhutan  (the  Government)  for  the 
Micro,  Small,  and  Medium-Sized  Enterprise  Sector  Development 
Program (MSME SDP) comprising (i) a program grant of $6 million 
for  policy  reforms  (the  Program);  and  (ii)  a  project  grant  of  $9 
million  to  extend  credit  to  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized 
enterprises (MSMEs), support business development, and facilitate 
program implementation (the Project).  
 
Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Industry and trade 
Subsector: Small and medium-scale enterprises 
Themes:  Sustainable 
growth, 
development

The  credit  facility  which  forms  part  of  the  Project  grant  where  all 
subprojects  are  to  be  financed  is  expected  to  have  insignificant 
impacts,  and  a  basic  environmental  management  system

Involuntary resettlement: category C 
Impact on indigenous people: category C 
No  involuntary  resettlement  or  impact  on  indigenous  people  is 
expected from program implementation.  
 
While  Bhutan  has  experienced  strong  economic  growth  of  about 
7%  per  annum  on  average  since  the  1980s,  poverty  remains  a 
social and economic issue, as an estimated 32% of the population 
is  poor.  Moreover,  recent  economic  growth  has  depended heavily 
on  the  hydropower  industry  and  its  auxiliary  sectors,  which  have 
low employment elasticity (i.e., sensitivity of growth of employment 
with respect to sector growth). As over 40% of the total labor force 
depends on the agricultural sector, and as the development of the 
agricultural  sector  has  been  declining,  it  is  of  concern  to  the 
Government that the issues of narrow-based economic growth and 
employment  generation  are  addressed  quickly.  Of  serious 
immediate  concern  is  the  estimated  50,000  youths  about  to  enter 
the labor market and another 20,000 people migrating to the urban 
areas by the end of 2007. As the public sector is not in a position to 
absorb  the  additional  labor  force,  even  in  the  short  term,  it  is 
imperative  that  Bhutan  diversifies  its  economic  activities  by 
promoting  the  development  of  the  private  sector  in  order  to  move 
to  a  more  stable,  sustainable,  and  broad-based  economic  growth 
path and to generate much-needed employment.

The  private  sector  of  Bhutan  is  small,  consisting  of  significant 
numbers  of  MSMEs,  and 
faces  a  number  of  development 
constraints.  Consequently,  the  Government  has  prioritized  the 
promotion of MSME development in the Ninth Five-Year Plan, and 
has  also  included  the  focus  on  micro  and  small  industries, 
especially  in  rural  areas.  In  line  with  the  Government’s  strategic 
priorities for national development, the MSME SDP is proposed to 
support the promotion of the MSME sector, address the constraints 
of  MSME  development,  generate  employment  opportunities,  and 
enhance  overall  economic  growth.  The  MSME  SDP  design  also 
complements  the  Government’s  sector  development  priorities,  in 
which  the  private  sector  is  expected  to  play  a  vital  role  as  the 
engine of economic growth. The MSME SDP is fully consistent with 
the  priority  focus  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country 
strategy and complements ADB’s ongoing interventions to promote 
good  governance,  the  development  of  the  financial  sector,  and 
capacity  development  of  the  key  financial  institution  for  MSME 
the  MSME  SDP  design  being 
financing. 
complementary  with  ongoing  assistance 
funded  by  other 
development  partners,  considerable  synergy  is  expected  as  a 
result of program implementation.  
 
The overall objective of the proposed MSME SDP is to promote the 
expansion  and  growth  of  a  vibrant  MSME  sector  and  encourage 
private sector development for broad-based sustainable economic 
growth and employment. To achieve this goal, the MSME SDP will 
consist  of  a  program  grant  to  address  policy  reforms  and 
strengthening  of  the  enabling  environment,  and  a  project  grant  to 
provide  the  required  funding  otherwise  not  available  from  the 
domestic market due to market failure. 
 
The  Program  objectives  include  (i)  establishing  an  integrated 
policy,  strategy,  and 
for  MSME 
institutional 
development;  (ii)  enhancing  business  laws  and  regulations  to 
facilitate MSME operations; (iii) increasing access to market-based 
finance; and (iv) strengthening business support infrastructure. 
 
It  is  proposed  that  ADB  supports  the  Government’s  policy  reform 
program  by  providing  a  Program  grant  of  $6  million  from  ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources.  The  Program  grant  proceeds  are 
expected to be utilized over a period of 36 months from the date of 
grant effectiveness. 
 
The  MSME  SDP  will  be  for  3  years.  The  Program  grant  will  be 
released  in  three  tranches.  The  first  tranche  (not  exceeding  $2 
million)  is  to  be  disbursed  after  grant  effectiveness  and  upon 
satisfactory  fulfillment  of  the  first  tranche  conditions.  The  second 
tranche  (not  exceeding  $2  million)  will  be  disbursed  18  months 
after  the  first  tranche,  subject  to  satisfactory  fulfillment  of  the 
second 
tranche  (not 
exceeding $2 million) will be disbursed 18 months after the second

tranche,  subject  to  satisfactory  fulfillment  of  the  corresponding 
tranche  release  conditions.  The  policy  matrix  lists  all  the  tranche 
release conditions and policy reform actions (Appendix 4). 
 
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the Executing Agency for the 
MSME  SDP.  The  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry  (MTI)  will  be  the 
implementing  agency  (IA)  for  the  overall  Program,  other  than  for 
two  specific  policy  reform  actions:  (i)  the  restructuring  of  the 
Bhutan  Development  Finance  Corporation  (BDFC),  for  which 
BDFC  will  serve  as  the  IA;  and  (ii)  improving  quality  control  and 
product  standards,  for  which  the  Standards  and  Quality  Control 
Authority will be the IA. To ensure appropriate coordination of the 
Program  and  Project,  an  interagency  program  steering  committee 
will be set up. It will consist of, among others, representatives from 
MOF,  MTI,  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture,  and  the  Royal  Monetary 
Authority, with the MTI secretary as chair.  
 
The Program grant proceeds will be disbursed for a broad range of 
imports,  subject  to  a  list  of  ineligible  items  (Appendix  5).  All 
procurement  of  goods  and  services  produced  in,  and  originating 
from, ADB member countries will be made with due consideration 
to  economy  and  efficiency, 
in  accordance  with  standard 
Government  procedures  and  normal  private  sector  commercial 
practices  acceptable  to  ADB.  The  disbursement  of  the  Program 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Simplification  of 
grant  will  be 
Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program 
Loans  (1998,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  Borrower  will 
certify  that  the  value  of  total  imports  minus  (i)  imports  from 
nonmember countries, (ii) ineligible imports, and (iii) disbursements 
made  under  other  official  development  assistance,  is  greater  than 
the  amount  expected  to  be  disbursed  during  the  year.  ADB  will 
have the right to audit the use of the grant proceeds and to verify 
the accuracy of the Borrower's certification. 
 
The Government will use the local currency funds generated by the 
Program  grant  to  meet  Program  expenditures  and  associated 
reform costs. The Government will also provide counterpart funds, 
primarily in kind, to provide facilities for consulting services and to 
finance taxes and duties on equipment. 
 
The  Project  will  comprise:  (i)  a  credit  facility  through  BDFC  for 
financing the medium- to long-term credit requirements of MSMEs, 
particularly  rural  enterprises;  (ii)  a  cost-sharing  facility  to  provide 
necessary  technical  and  knowledge  support  to  MSMEs  that  have 
growth  potential  but  face  specified  constraints;  and  (iii)  capacity-
building support for program implementation and institution building 
to  ensure  the  formulation  and  execution  of  sustainable  MSME 
policy and strategies, and to ensure smooth implementation of the 
Government’s MSME development program.

There  are  three  potential  risk  situations  which  may  affect  the 
intended  outcomes  of  the  MSME  SDP.  The  MSME  SDP  has 
incorporated  mitigating  measures  as  appropriate  to  attenuate  the 
impacts associated with these risks.  
 
The first category of possible risk during program implementation is 
the  slowing down  of  policy  momentum.  This  may  occur  in  Bhutan 
as  the  country  is  in  the  process  of  transition  into  a  parliamentary 
democracy  in  2008.  Policy  reversal  is  unlikely,  as  the  present 
policies  of  the  ruling  monarchy  are  expected  to  continue  and  to 
have wide support, as the two major parties for the 2008 elections 
stand  by  existing  policies  and  further  emphasize  preservation  of 
heritage  and  tradition  along  with  economic  development  and 
employment  generation.  Likewise, 
is 
decidedly  conservative  and  supports  state  policies.  In  addition,  a 
parliamentary  democracy  is  likely  to  enhance  the  broad-based 
ownership of the reform actions rather than pose a risk to ongoing 
reforms.  The  national  development 
focus  on  private  sector 
development  and  promotion  of  MSMEs,  particularly  in  the  rural 
areas, has been embedded and prioritized in all Government policy 
and strategy documents, including the Ninth Five-Year Plan (2002–
2007), Bhutan 2020 Vision, and Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper 
(2004).  In  addition,  the  Government  has  established  a  private 
sector  working  group  to  assist  in  the  formulation  of  the  next 
midterm  development  strategy—the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan,  which 
indicates a continuing important role for MSME development in the 
national agenda.  
 
The activities and policy reforms for MSME development involve a 
cross-section  of  Bhutan’s  economy  and  various  ministries. 
Therefore,  close  coordination  among 
relevant  government 
agencies  and  with  the  private  sector,  principally  through  the  local 
industry 
chamber  of  commerce  and 
associations, 
to  support  and  oversee  program  and  project 
implementation  is  necessary.  The  lack  of,  or  weakness  of,  such

 coordination poses the second possible area of risk to the success 
of  the  MSME  SDP.  To  mitigate  such  risk,  the  MSME  SDP  will 
ensure  smooth  implementation  through  an  adequate  institutional 
mechanism  at  two  levels:  a  program  steering  committee  at  the 
interministerial  level,  and  a  dedicated  MSME  division  at  the 
implementation level with private sector representation. To ensure 
a  participatory  consultation  process  and  public-private  partnership 
under  the  MSME  SDP,  proper  private  sector  representation  is 
assured through the active participation of the Bhutan Chamber of 
Commerce  and  Industry  in  the  MSME  division,  in  order  to 
contribute to the reform process and provide feedback on program 
and  project  implementation.  In  addition,  an  enhanced  Private 
Sector  Development  Committee  (formed  in  2002)  with  increased 
private  sector  representation  or  such  a  body  as  may  be  designed 
for  the  same  purpose  after  the  ongoing  ministerial  organizational 
development  process  designed  to  improve  the  efficiency  of 
Government  offices,  agencies,  and  state-owned  enterprises  is 
completed, will, with the support of the MSME division, serve in an 
advisory  capacity  to  help  in  the  formulation  of  policy  for  MSME 
development.  
 
The  third  possible  risk  area  is  that  of  limited  institutional  capacity 
for proper implementation of the Program and Project components, 
particularly  the  implementation  of  the  credit  line  at  BDFC  and  the 
cost-sharing facility at MTI. The risks associated with this capacity 
constraint  will  be  addressed  by  allocating  adequate  resources  to 
provide  technical  support  to  involved  agencies.  The  technical 
support  to  BDFC  will  be  provided  by  the  ongoing  technical 
assistance  which  will  prepare  the  5-year  business  plan  and 
strategy,  and  subsequently  assist  in  implementing  the  business 
plan  and  skills  training  for  better  MSME  lending  and  effective 
credit-line assistance. Parallel reforms under the ongoing Financial 
Sector  Development  Program  will  address  corporate  governance 
issues  and  adherence  to  prudential  standards  of  operation. 
Subproject 3 will provide capacity building to the MSME division to 
support the implementation, management, and disbursement of the 
cost-sharing facility. Other relevant capacity-development supports 
to  involved  agencies,  such  as  the  Standards  and  Quality  Control 
Authority, are also incorporated into subproject 3 to ensure smooth 
program implementation.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  proposed 
Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Sector Development Program (MSME SDP) for the 
Kingdom of Bhutan, consisting of (i) a program grant to support policy reforms; and (ii) a project 
grant  to  extend  credit  to  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs),  support 
business development, and facilitate program implementation.  
 

II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Sector Description and Performance 

 
A. 
 
Background. Bhutan is in the eastern Himalaya and is landlocked between the world’s 
2. 
two most populous nations—the People’s Republic of China and India. It has one of the most 
formidable  mountainous  terrains  in  the  world,  ranging  from  200  meters  (m)  to  7,500  m  in 
altitude.  The  total  land  area  is  38,394  square  kilometers,  72%  of  which  is  covered  by  forest. 
Land  use  is  correlated  with  altitude  and  climate.  Bhutan  is  administratively  divided  into  20 
dzongkhags  (districts),  which  are  further  broken  down  into  201  gewogs  (blocks).  According  to 
the  Population  and  Housing  Census  2005,  the  total  population  of  Bhutan  is  about  634,982, 
around 70% of whom live in rural areas.  
 
3. 
Macroeconomic Performance. Bhutan has experienced strong economic performance 
with  steady  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  averaging  around  7%  per  annum  since  the 
1980s. However, despite strong economic growth, poverty in Bhutan still remains a social and 
economic  issue,  as  an  estimated  32%  of  the  population  still  live  below  the  poverty  line.1  The 
high  growth  has  increased  GDP  per  capita  to  almost  $1,3002  in  2005,3  from  $834  in  2004, 
mainly driven by the growth in the hydropower and auxiliary sectors. The commissioning of the 
1,020  megawatt  Tala  project  will  have  a  significant  impact  on  the  economy  in  terms  of 
generating  revenues  from  electricity  exports,  especially  when  the  project  reaches  full  capacity 
after the monsoon season starts in May–June 2007. GDP growth is forecast4 to be about 9% in 
2006 and 18% in 2007 in nominal terms (see Supplementary Appendix A). 
 
Overall  Sector  Structure  and  Performance.  Sector  performance  has  been  strong  in 
4. 
the  hydropower  and  its  related  industries.  The  electricity  sales  were  10%  of  overall  nominal 
GDP in 2005. The share of the manufacturing and construction sectors (including hydropower-
related  construction)  is  also  significant,  accounting  for  26%  in  2004  and  24.3%  in  2005.  The 
GDP  share  of  the  trade  sector5  averaged  only  about  5.5%  during  2004–2005.  The  services 
sector6  increased,  primarily  due  to  the  growth  in  the  tourism  industry  and,  more  recently,  the 
financial sector.7 It accounted for 22.9% of GDP in 2004 and 27.4% in 2005. The share of the

Need to Promote Private Sector Development. Bhutan’s economy is dependent upon 
5. 
a  narrow  base  for  economic  growth.  High  dependence  on  the  hydropower  sector  and  low 
productivity in the agriculture sector thus raise serious concerns about the long-term prospects 
for economic development and employment in the country. As the hydropower sector has low 
employment elasticity (i.e. sensitivity of growth of employment with respect to sector growth), it 
is essential for the country to diversify economic activity to generate employment, raise income 
levels for the poor, and achieve stable, sustainable, and broad-based economic growth. In this 
regard, the Government of Bhutan (the Government) has placed a high priority on private sector 
development,  particularly  in  view  of  the  need  to  absorb  an  estimated  50,000  young  people 
entering  the  labor  market  and  another  20,000  people  migrating  to  urban  areas  by  the  end  of 
2007.  
 
Significance  and  Definition  of  the  MSME  Sector.  The  private  sector  in  Bhutan 
6. 
comprises  micro,  small,  medium,  and  large  enterprises.  The  official  classification  is  based  on 
initial  capital  investment  which,  by  definition,  consists  of  paid-in  capital  and  long-term  credit. 
Each business is registered under one of the above-mentioned categories and has a business 
license  that  needs  to  be  renewed  annually.  Following  the  industrial  classification  method,8 
manufacturing and services micro enterprises are businesses with investment of less than Nu1 
million,  small  enterprises  have  investment  of  between  Nu1  million  and  Nu10  million,  medium 
enterprises have investment of between Nu10 million and Nu100 million, and large enterprises 
have  investment  of  more  than  Nu100  million.  Approximately  93%  of  the  newly  established 
businesses  over  the  past  5  years  are  MSMEs.  In  2006,  the  estimated  number  of  MSMEs  in 
Bhutan  was  16,557  (13,677  micro,  2,658  small,  and  222  medium-sized  enterprises)  (see 
Appendix  1).  The  significant  number  of  MSMEs,  especially  micro  and  small  enterprises, 
indicates the predominant role of MSMEs in private sector development.  
 
B. 
 
The  Government  is  aware  of  the  significance  of  the  MSME  sector  and  has  therefore 
7. 
targeted it (especially rural-based businesses) in its private sector development efforts, with the 
aim  of  enhancing  overall  economic  growth.  However,  despite  Government  efforts,  including 
commitment to private sector development in the country’s 5-year development plans since the 
late 1980s, the MSME sector remains weak (typically one-person shop operations) and thus is 
yet  to  generate  employment  opportunities  or  serve  as  the  engine  of  growth  as  envisaged. 
MSME development continues to face the following challenges.9

Institutional 

 
8. 
Absence  of  a  Clear  Vision,  Integrated  Policy,  and  Long-Term  Strategy  for  MSME 
Development. The development of the MSME sector in Bhutan is characterized by significant 
fragmentation of decision making, the lack of strategic guidance, and weak coordination among 
relevant  ministries  and  agencies.  Currently,  Government  assistance  for  sector  development  is 
formulated  and  implemented  on  an  ad  hoc  basis  without  systematic  assessment  and/or 
comprehensive  studies  on  the  forward  linkage  and  supply  chain  of  the  targeted  product  or 
industry.  For  example,  tourism,  agro-processing,  wood,  and  wood-based  industries  are 
identified as growth areas for private sector development in Bhutan. However, there is yet to be 
any consistent or coherent sector or product development strategy at an industry or sector level 
to  improve  the  market  competitiveness  of  these  industries.  Nor  does  the  Government  have  a 
coordination  mechanism  or  framework  across  ministries  and  government  agencies  to  collect 
feedback,  reach  consensus,  and  guide  the  target  sector  and/or  industry  to  develop  the  value 
chains  or  clusters  for  sustainable  business  development.  Despite  ongoing  external  assistance 
from  other  development  partners  (see  Section  E:  External  Assistance  to  the  Sector  for  more 
detail), there is a great need for the Government to develop a clear and comprehensive country 
development policy and strategy for effectively addressing the challenges and constraints faced 
by the MSME sector.  
 
9. 
is 
coordination  between  public  and  private  sectors  that  allows  for  input  from  private  sector 
representatives,  public-private  interaction  remains  inadequate  for  the  stimulation  of  business 
development.  In  2000,  the  Government  established  a  private  sector  development  committee 
(PSDC)  to  initiate  and coordinate  supportive  policies  and programs.  However,  the  structure of 
the  PSDC  has  proved  to  be  too  large  and  it  lacked  sufficient  authority  to  perform  its  tasks 
effectively,  which  has  resulted  in  a  defunct  entity.10  In  2005,  the  PSDC  was  revived  with  a 
slimmer  structure  and  also  with  increased  private  sector  participation.11  However,  to  put  the 
guiding  policy,  development  strategy,  and  regulation  for  private  sector  development  into 
practice,  there  is  an  apparent  need  to  further  strengthen  the  current  institutional  structure  for 
more efficient decision making, administration, and coordination.

Inadequate  Business  Laws  and  Regulations.  Bhutanese  laws  are  often  drafted  or

Cumbersome  Business  Formalization  Process.  There  is  a  complex  and  time 
11. 
consuming  business  formalization  process  in  Bhutan.  A  multitude  of  business  and  sectoral 
licenses  are  required,  and  these  are  often  duplicative  and  burdensome.  Compliance 
requirements,  such  as  supporting  documents  and  clearances,  are  overlapping  and  numerous. 
The  World  Bank’s  Doing  Business  reports  was  recently  updated,  and  on  the  indicators  of 
starting  a  business,  it  ranks  Bhutan  79  out  of  175  countries.12  Starting  a  business  previously 
involved 11 procedures, and this has been reduced to 10, takes 62 days, and costs 16.6% of 
per  capita  income.13  In  2005,  MTI  initiated  several  measures  to  reduce  the  business 
formalization  process  and  it  currently  takes  43  days  to  receive  licenses  for  starting  up  a 
business; international good practice suggests 21 days.  
 
 
 
12.  Market Failure in MSME Financing, particularly in Rural Areas. As is the case with 
other  developing  countries,  especially  in  the  early  growth  stage,  limited  access  to  finance  is 
identified  as  a  continuing  fundamental  constraint  for  doing  business.  It  is  even  more  so  in 
Bhutan, particularly for micro and small businesses and those in rural areas.14 The constraint is 
attributable  mainly  to  a  segmented  lending  market  caused  by  extremely  high  collateral 
requirements and low banking intermediation. The two commercial banks, the Bank of Bhutan 
(BOB) and the Bhutan National Bank (BNB), operate at the low-risk end of the market, mainly in 
urban areas, and require considerable collateral (up to 200% of the liability), while the Bhutan 
Development Finance Corporation (BDFC) lends to MSMEs, both in urban and rural areas and 
apparently has poor liquidity and limited sources of funds.15 In addition, due to a lack of suitable 
collateral, reliable credit information, and thus an inability to appropriately assess risk, most of 
the  credit  has  been  channeled  to  large  to  medium-sized  enterprises  which  can  meet  high 
collateral  requirements,  leaving  the  majority  of  MSMEs  with  insufficient  financing  and  limited 
access to credit. Local sources of medium- to long-term finance remain scarce as the domestic 
capital market is still in its formative stages. 
 
13. 
Insufficient  Institutional  Capacity  among  Financial  Institutions.  Limited  access  to 
credit by MSMEs is also largely attributed to institutional deficiencies within the existing financial 
institutions,  such  as  (i)  corporate  governance,  (ii)  strategic  business  planning,  (iii)  risk 
management, (iv) product development, (v) human-resources development, and (vi) information 
technology (IT). BOB and BNB, which mainly lend to large and medium-sized enterprises, have 
signed  memoranda  of  understanding  with  the  SouthAsia  Enterprise  Development  Facility

there is a need to strengthen BDFC’s role and capacity for MSME lending.16 The introduction of

Shortage  of  Long-Term  Funding  at  BDFC.  BDFC  has  unrivalled  outreach  in  rural 
14. 
areas and is mandated to focus on micro enterprise and rural lending. As of the end of 2005, 
BDFC  had  14,764  active  clients  in  rural  areas,  or  17.2%  of  total  rural  households.  BDFC  has 
44% of the total clients17 in the financial market, and as of the end of 2006 it had over 90% of 
rural lending in Bhutan. Because of its social mandate, existing nationwide branch network, and 
better MSME lending skills in comparison with the other two banks, BDFC is seen as the most 
appropriate agency to help overcome the financial constraints of the MSME sector, particularly 
in rural areas. However, as a nonbank financial institution, BDFC does not have direct access to 
the domestic savings market except the recent rural saving program which the Royal Monetary 
Authority  (RMA)  has  issued  licenses  for.  The  sources  of  funds  are  therefore  mainly  external 
loans and grants from international agencies, such as ADB, the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic 
Development, and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. In the past, BDFC was 
able to occasionally raise medium-term funds locally from National Pension and Provident Fund, 
BNB, and BOB, using some of the excess liquidity of the financial sector then in Bhutan.  
 
15. 
Lack of Credit Information on MSMEs. Another impediment to sustained growth of the 
private  sector  in  Bhutan  is  the  lack  of  credit  information  and  the  mechanism  to  collect  such 
information in order for lenders to be able to identify profitable projects in a risky environment. 
Consequently, the provision of financial services is restricted to low-risk clients or is based on 
excessive collateral requirements instead of on a credit analysis relying on repayment capability 
based on financial performance and statements and business plans. Therefore, a more flexible 
and dynamic credit information system will improve the accuracy and cost effectiveness of credit 
risk decisions made by financial institutions (e.g., by cutting down on credit appraisal time and 
decreasing  reliance  on  collateral).  This,  in  turn,  will  result  in  improved  access  to  financial 
services,  in  particular,  for  small  businesses  and  individual  borrowers.  Because  of  the 
importance and urgency of this issue, ADB has provided support to the establishment of a credit 
information bureau under the Financial Sector Development Program (FSDP) in 2006.18 
 
Limited Secured Financing. The credit information supporting system is also weak with 
16. 
regard  to  the  collateralization  of  transactions.  In  general,  at  the  lower  end  of  the  rural  finance 
market, social pressure is used to secure micro loans. In the middle segment, comprising small 
farmers  and  MSMEs,  access  to  affordable  medium-  to  long-term  credit  is  constrained  by  little 
property  or  imperfect  title  to  small  parcels  of  land.  However,  MSMEs  usually  have  significant 
movable  assets  (e.g.,  equipment,  inventory,  and  accounts  receivable).  Enabling  borrowers  to 
use these movable assets and rights to secure their indebtedness opens up new possibilities for 
MSMEs  to  access  finance  and  make  fuller  economic  use  of  their  assets.  However,  in  Bhutan 
there is limited secured financing to ease high collateral requirements.

17 However, due to low average loan size, BDFC has only 12% of total principal outstanding.

17. 
The main reason for limited secured financing is that the existing system of registration 
of mortgages and charges is fragmented. There is no central registry to allow for the verification 
of interests, especially movable property such as working equipment used as collateral. Lacking 
access  to  a  proper  central  registry,  the  borrower  must  first  obtain  a  clearance  from  every 
financial  institution  to  certify  that  there  is  no  preexisting  claim.  This  cumbersome  process 
causes  delays  in  loan  processing  and  involves  high  costs  for  the  financial  institutions  and  the 
clients.  Bhutanese  regulations  regarding  secured  transactions  are  set  out  in  the  Loan  Act 
(1981),  the  Companies  Act  (2000),  and  the  Movable  and  Immovable  Property  Act  (1999),  the 
provisions  of  which  call  for  the  registration  of  mortgages  and  charges.  Even  though  there  are 
two land registrars at the central and local level, they only maintain records on ownership and 
not  on  collateralization  of  land  and  buildings.  The  Thimphu  City  Corporation  has  recently 
approached  the  financial  institutions  and  requested  them  to  forward  to  the  Thimphu  City 
Corporation the mortgage details of all the properties within the Thimphu Urban Municipality in 
order to build up an information base on the status of all mortgages. However, so far there has 
been  no  response  from  the  financial  institutions.  Under  the  Road  Safety  and  Transport 
Authority, a registry exists where charges on cars have been registered. Under the Ministry of 
Trade  and  Industry  (MTI),  a  registry  of  charges  was  set  up;  however,  it  only  applies  to 
incorporated companies. As a result, the fragmented and nontransparent system of registration 
of collateralized mortgages and charges in Bhutan needs to be further improved to better record 
and  monitor  mortgages  and  charges,  and  thereby  secure  “lender–borrower/creditor-debtor” 
transactions to effectively facilitate access to credit.  
 
18. 
Ineffective Government Credit and Credit Guarantee Assistance Schemes. In 1987, 
the  Government  launched  a  credit  scheme  for  small  enterprises  (small  businesses  and 
artisans).  This  scheme  was  a  failure  as  about  96%  of  loans  defaulted,  and  was  consequently 
discontinued in the mid-1990’s. The main problem was that the client’s perception was of having 
received  a  grant  rather  than  a  loan  from  the  Government.  In  1992,  the  Government  launched 
the  Entrepreneurs  Development  Program  Loan  Scheme  (EDPLS),  for  Nu100  million,  intended 
for  individuals  who  had  successfully  completed  the  Comprehensive  Entrepreneurship  Course. 
The  absence  of  personal  risk  was  felt  to  have  eroded  the  commitment  to  repay,  thus 
nonperforming  loans  were  high.  Consequently,  financial  institutions  became  risk-averse  and 
were reluctant to approve further loans to MSMEs. Until early 2005, only 48 entrepreneurs (less 
than 20% of the 258 Comprehensive Entrepreneurship Course graduates) had received a loan, 
out of which only 25 are currently running their businesses successfully. The loan scheme was 
subsequently adjusted; equity contribution and some collateral are now required.  
 
19. 
In 2003, to further support self-employment, the Government complemented the EDPLS 
with a credit guarantee scheme (CGS) through the two commercial banks. The Small Business 
Resources Center under the Bhutan Export Promotion Center acts on behalf of the Government 
to  (i)  appraise  proposals  for  eligible  applicants,  (ii)  provide  support,  and  (iii)  maintain  the 
guarantee  fund.  Neither  equity  contribution  nor  collateral  is  required,  and  the  Government 
covers  60%  of  the  credit  risk  to  the  financial  institutions.  Due  to  the  relatively  short 
implementation time of the CGS its effectiveness cannot yet be determined. 
 
 
 
20. 
Lack  of  Market  Information  and  Technical  Expertise.  Key  impediments  to  private 
sector growth in Bhutan are the lack of available information and mechanisms to collect market 
information,  and  limited  technical  expertise.  Most  of  the  MSMEs  in  Bhutan  are  still  in  their 
infancy,  selling  their  products  locally  or,  at  best,  nationwide,  and  have  yet  to  be  exposed  to 
international  markets  and  competition.  In  addition,  it  is  particularly  difficult  for  MSMEs  in  rural 

Inadequate Business Support Infrastructure 

4. 

6 

 

 7 

areas to gather relevant business information on things such as prices, products, technologies, 
and  markets,  and  to  employ  external  services  to  improve  business  performance.  With  Bhutan 
becoming a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the near future, competition for 
businesses  is  very  likely  to  increase  and  this  poses  an  urgent  need  for  increasing 
competitiveness of MSMEs via promotion and enhancement of business development services 
(BDS) in Bhutan.  
 
21. 
BDS  refers  to  consulting  support  for  training,  and  access  to  technology,  marketing, 
information,  and  markets.  Traditionally,  the  government  delivers  BDS  via  public  providers  or 
government-subsidized  programs,  and  this  tends  to  be  supply-driven.  However,  these 
interventions  have  had  the  tendency  to  (i)  impinge  upon  existing  or  potential  commercially 
oriented service providers, (ii) have questionable long-term sustainability, and (iii) have difficulty 
in  developing  a  discerning  client  culture  among  MSMEs.19  According  to  the  findings  of  the 
MSME  market  survey,20  the  Government  dominates  the  provision  of  MSME  BDS,  providing 
training  such  as  bookkeeping,  management,  and  accounting.  Nonetheless,  commercial  BDS 
also exists, overlapping in the areas of fully subsidized BDS in addition to providing demand-led 
services.21 The coexistence of public and private BDS indicates a potential opportunity for the 
Government  to  fully  develop  the  private  sector  BDS  market,  especially  in  view  of  its  current 
limited  outreach  due  to  the  small  number  of  MSMEs  that  can  be  served  through  limited 
government subsidies. Focusing on the promotion of BDS markets is not only a sustainable way 
for improving BDS but also an effective approach, as proven by practical experience. Bhutan’s 
MSME  market  survey  also  reveals  that  there  are  only  either  commercial  fully  paid  or  fully 
subsidized  BDS  available  and  no  partially  financed  or  cofinanced  BDS  arrangements,  which 
indicates  another  opportunity,  as  a  transition  mechanism  to  promote  fully  market-based  BDS 
and increase the outreach and sustainability of BDS programs.  
 
22. 
Incomplete  Legal  and  Organizational  Frameworks  for  Standards  and  Quality 
Control.  To  ensure  the  quality  of  enterprises’  products  and  services  in  order  to  increase 
competitiveness and market access, it is very important to establish national standards and for 
relevant  international  standards  to  be  adopted  and  implemented  in  manufacturing  goods  and 
services,  and  to  reduce  technical  barriers  to  trade.  However,  the  development  of  standards, 
metrology,22  and  conformity  assessment  in  Bhutan  are  at  a  very  rudimentary  stage;  currently, 
the legal framework for standards and quality is incomplete. The draft Standards Act, which has 
been  approved  by  the  Government,  is  to  be  submitted  to,  and  enacted  by,  the  National 
Assembly.  The setting of standards and other regulatory tasks are fragmented among various 
Government agencies.23 In addition, apparently no coordination body or authority in place that 
would  safeguard  (i)  harmonious  development  of  standards,  regulations,  and  conformity 
assessment  procedures;  and  (ii)  the  preparation,  adoption,  and  application  of  standards  and

Priority  for  standards  setting  has  been  identified  in  the  food  and  agricultural  products

Agricultural  and  Food  Regulatory  Authority  (BAFRA),  established  in  August  2000  and 
functioning  as  a  food  inspector,  plays  an  important  role  for  the  development  of  standards  for 
agricultural-based products. BAFRA24 has a strong presence all over Bhutan and operates three 
laboratories  to  regulate  the  quality  of  products  that  are  either  locally  produced  or  imported  for 
further  processing  for  export  or  the  domestic  market.  However,  BAFRA  is  currently 
understaffed,  and  its  existing  staff,  both  in  the  field  and  laboratory,  lack  the  experience, 
international exposure, and qualifications to undertake food quality and standards setting. The 
existing laboratory equipment also needs to be upgraded to meet modern standards.

The  Government’s  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan  2002–200725  was  prepared  in  line  with  the 
24. 
Government’s  long-term  strategy  framework  (Bhutan  2020  Vision)  and  the  National  Poverty 
Reduction  Strategy  2004,  both  of  which  clearly  reflect  the  priority  of  private  sector  growth  for 
employment generation. Recognizing that hydropower development will continue to play a vital 
role in economic growth, diversifying the economic activity to boost employment is central to the 
Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy.  This  is  to  be  accomplished  by,  among  other  things, 
improving  the  private  sector  enabling  environment,  boosting  the  efficiency  of  the  financial 
sector,  and  steadily  enhancing  institutional  capacity  and  human  resources.  In  addition,  the 
Government  places  emphasis  on micro  and  small  industries,  especially  those  which  are  rural-
based, to provide more off-farm employment opportunities to alleviate the poverty that is seen 
more  in  rural  than  urban  areas.  The  development  strategy  emphasizes  skills  training  for 
business development and marketing, as well as loans to rural enterprises, which will continue 
to be provided by BDFC.

III. 

THE PROPOSED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 

Important Features 

Impact and Outcome 

 
A. 
 
33. 
The overall objective of the proposed MSME SDP is to promote a vibrant MSME sector 
and  encourage  private  sector  development  for  sustainable  economic  growth.  To  achieve  this 
goal  and  the  envisaged  impact,  the  MSME  SDP  consists  of  a  Program  grant  and  a  Project 
grant. The Program grant will address the needed policy reforms to develop a policy framework, 
a  long-term  vision  and  strategy,  and  a  sector  development  program,  designed  to  create  an 
enabling  environment  for  MSMEs.  The  Project  grant,  which  consists  of  three  subprojects,  is 
designed  to  (i)  improve  access  to,  and  increase,  affordable  credit  for  MSMEs,  particularly  in 
rural  areas;  (ii)  fill  viability  gaps  and  improve  the  provision  of  BDS  to  increase  market 
competitiveness of MSMEs; and (iii) provide support for program implementation and capacity 
building as required to implement specific MSME SDP components. The expected outcome of 
the  MSME  SDP  is  a  more  conducive  business  environment  for  more  active  private  sector 
participation (particularly MSMEs), contributing to broad-based economic development.  
 
B. 
 
34. 
There  are  three  important  features  in  the  MSME  SDP  design.  Firstly,  the  Program 
prioritizes  the  policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  reform  agenda,  complementing  the  Project 
design of investment and technical support, for an integrated and holistic approach to develop 
the  private  sector.  The  Program’s  policy  and  regulatory  reform  emphasizes  the  creation  of  a 
conducive business environment, which has been proven to generate larger impacts on micro, 
small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  than  large  ones.  In  addition,  the  Program’s  institutional 
reform  addresses  the  urgent  need  to  establish  an  MSME  coordination  unit  to  formulate, 
coordinate, implement, and monitor a long-term MSME policy and strategy, which is also crucial 
for pursuing MSME development.  
 
Secondly,  the  MSME  SDP  provides  an  inclusive  growth  strategy  to  not  only  increase 
35. 
economic growth opportunities but also focus on ensuring the participation of micro and small 
enterprises  in  the  growth  process.  The  Program  and  Project  design  incorporate  necessary 
measures, including credits to MSMEs and capacity development, as identified by the country 
assistance  program  evaluation  2005  and  the  country  strategy  and  program  2006–2010,  to 
address the key constraints facing the private sector in Bhutan.  
 
36. 
Thirdly,  the  MSME  SDP  design  complements  the  ongoing  ADB  FSDP  and  TA  4837 
(footnote  16)  to  improve  access  to  finance  and  bring  the  rural  sector  into  the  formal  financial 
system.  The  proposed  credit  line  (subproject  1  under  the  Project  grant)  will  be  implemented 
along  with  the  implementation  of  the  ongoing  TA  4837  which  will  prepare  and,  equally 
importantly,  implement  a  new  5-year  business  plan  and  strategy  for  BDFC  to  focus  and 
enhance  MSME  financing.  In  addition,  the  promotion  of  secured  transactions  through  the 
establishment  of  a  central  registry  (subproject  3  of  the  Project  grant)  will  complement  the 
establishment  of  a  credit  information  bureau  under  the  FSDP  so  as  to  make  reliable  credit 
information  available  and  reduce  transaction  costs  for  better  credit  decisions  by  financial 
institutions. In turn, it will enhance the efficiency of the credit line disbursement of subproject 1, 
resulting  in  maximizing  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  ADB  development  assistance  with  the 
limited resources available to Bhutan.

The Program 

1. 

Objectives 

 
37. 
The  Program  objective  is  to  initiate  and  undertake  necessary  policy  reforms  to  (i) 
establish an integrated policy, strategy, and institutional framework for MSME development; (ii) 
enhance  business  laws  and  regulations  to  facilitate  MSME  operations;  (iii)  increase  access  to 
market-based finance; and (iv) strengthen the business support infrastructure. The Program is 
intended to stimulate the expansion and growth of the MSME sector and overall private sector 
development.  
 

2.

The  Program  consists  of  four  components.  The  output  and  performance  targets  of  the

39. 
The  Government  will  adopt  a  clear  policy  towards  supporting  and  promoting  MSME 
development.  This  policy  will  be  underpinned  by  a  competitiveness  study  to  determine  which 
key sectors and products have the greatest potential and comparative advantage for the country 
to  develop,  given  its  natural  resources.  As  part  of  this  study,  supply-chain  and  value-added 
analyses  are  to  be  conducted  to  determine  weak  links,  gaps,  and  forward  and  backward 
linkages  in  key  sectors  that  need  to  be  strengthened  and  filled.  The  study  will  help  focus 
government assistance, and will also help identify different measures that could mitigate these 
constraints  and  develop  market  mechanisms, 
the  development  of  clusters, 
subcontracting arrangements, and joint ventures.31  
 
The  Government  has  to  establish  an  appropriate  institutional  framework  and  structure 
40. 
within  which  to  effectively  deliver  Government  assistance  to  the  MSME  sector.  It  is  therefore 
considered  appropriate  to  centralize  functions  relating  to  MSME  development  within  the 
Government in order to pursue a well coordinated MSME policy and strategy. As a first step, the 
Government has revived the PSDC (to be renamed, or such a body as may be designed after 
the  currently  ongoing  ministerial  organizational  development  process  has  been  completed)  to 
act as an advisory body to assist in policy formulation for private sector development. However, 
one problem with the PSDC has been its inability to detail and implement policies and programs

MSME  development  strategy  and  policy,  to  be  immediately  adopted  for  supporting  MSME

b. 

Enhance  Business  Laws  and  Regulations  and  Facilitate  Business 
Processes  

 
41. 
Regulatory  Impact  Assessment.  To  improve  the  current  regulatory  practice  and 
ensure  the  regulators  adopt  prudent  regulations,  particularly  for  improving  the  regulatory 
framework for a more conducive business environment, the proposed Program will introduce a 
regulatory impact assessment (RIA) and pilot it on selected draft business laws. An RIA32 is a 
key tool used to assess the likely effects of a proposed new regulation or regulatory change. It 
involves  a  systematic  appraisal  of  the  costs  and  benefits  associated  with  new  and/or  existing 
laws  and  regulations,  and  a  detailed  analysis  to  ascertain  whether  or  not  the  new  regulation 
would  have  the  desired  impact.  RIA  also  includes  a  participative  process  and  mechanism 
allowing  all  relevant  stakeholders  to  express  their  views  in  open  discussions  and  to  form 
opinions  for  lawmaking  and  review  of  the  impacts  of  such  laws.  The  adoption  of  an  RIA  will 
improve  the  quality  of  lawmaking,  enhance  good  governance,  and  improve  the  regulatory 
capacity and performance of the Government. 
 
42. 
The  introduction,  adoption,  and  institutionalization  of  RIA  will  involve  four  phases.  In 
phase  one  (the  preparation  phase),  an  RIA  working  group  will  be  established,  and  the  RIA 
methodology  will  be  adapted  to  the  Bhutanese  context  and  introduced  to  public  and  private 
stakeholders. One of the tasks of the RIA working group is to prepare a short list of regulations 
to  be  reviewed.  In  the  second  phase  (the  pilot  phase),  the  RIA  working  group  will  review  two 
draft  laws  (currently  Draft  Bhutan  Enterprise  Registration  Act  and  Draft  Industries  and 
Investment  Act,  or  any  other  legislation  relevant  to  MSME  development)33  and  prepare 
assessment  reports  accordingly.  In  phase  three  (the  evaluation  phase),  the  feasibility  of 
institutionalizing  RIA  will  be  further  assessed.  This  will  include  a  thorough  assessment  of  the 
impact of a new RIA policy, which would provide the legal framework needed to institutionalize 
RIA.  The  purpose  of  this  policy  would  be  to  make  an  RIA  mandatory  before  adopting  a  new 
regulation,  as  well  as  to  evaluate  existing  regulations.  In  phase  four  (the  institutionalization 
phase),  RIA  policy  and  institutionalization  plan  (e.g.,  establishment  of  an  RIA  unit)  would  be 
formulated and approved for implementation. RIA is expected to be widely applied in all sectors 
in  the  future.  In  addition,  at  the  end  of  phase  four  and  based  on  the  RIA  pilot  exercises,  the 
reviewed  Bhutan  Enterprise  Registration  Act  and  Industries  and  Investment  Act  would  be 
revised accordingly and submitted to the National Assembly for consideration. 
 
43. 
Business  Formalization  Process.  The  main  objective  of  the  simplification  and 
acceleration of business formalization is to reduce the cost of doing business and promote the 
establishment  of  new  enterprises,  particularly  in  labor-intensive  manufacturing  and  service 
industries. The Government has made significant efforts to reduce the time and costs involved 
in the business formalization process. The overall time to start a business was decreased from 
62 to 47 days, as required by the  World Bank’s DPG. Since then the Government has further

 14 

reduced the days required for business formalization to 43 days. To support the envisaged long-
term  MSME  development  strategy  and  reduce  barriers  to  entry  for  MSMEs,  it  is  important  to 
further reduce the days taken for business formalization from 43 to 30 days, and to move closer 
to good international practice.  
 
44. 
One-Stop  Shops.  To  more  efficiently  handle  business  formalization  and  minimize 
bureaucratic procedures, the Government is considering introduction of single access points, or 
one-stop shops (OSSs) at the regional level through RTIOs. The introduction of an OSS, which 
handles business formalization and other bureaucratic processes under one roof, will increase 
efficiency and ease market entry for start-up businesses. Therefore, the MSME SDP proposes 
that the Government establishes an OSS working group, consisting of government officers from 
all  relevant  administrative  levels,  to  formulate  the  model  and  the  functions  of  the  OSS  and  to 
prepare the action plan to introduce OSSs in the six RTIOs. The Government will also prepare a 
brochure detailing the process of business formalization, with time and costs involved, for public 
dissemination.  Furthermore,  the  Government  will  introduce  OSS  benchmarks,  which  are 
necessary  to  standardize  services,  increase  efficiency  in  service  provision,  and  improve  the 
overall  quality  of  business  support  services.  The  benchmark  system  will  comprise  indicators 
covering  service  efficiency  and  service  quality  supported  by  an  appropriate  feedback  system. 
Authorities required for the proper functioning of OSSs are expected to be eventually delegated. 
However, in view of the multisectoral nature of the OSS, further consultation at the committee of 
secretaries34 level is required to ensure that the OSS option will work. 
 
45. 
Regional Trade and Industry Offices. In Bhutan, the following three government levels 
are involved in the business formalization process: (i) the central level of MTI and the Revenue 
and  Customs  Office,  (ii)  the  regional  level  of  RTIOs  and  the  regional  Revenue  and  Customs 
offices, and (iii) the authorities which issue local clearances at the local (dzongkhag) level. The 
establishment of OSS units in the six RTIOs at the regional level will help streamline and further 
reduce  the  time  needed  to  start  up  a  business.  Therefore,  as  the  responsibility  and 
accountability  of  RTIOs  increases,  the  Government  needs  to  commence  review  and  consider 
establishing  performance  benchmarks  and  a  monitoring  system  for  RTIOs.  The  performance 
benchmark  should  also  be  disseminated  to  the  public  and  RTIOs,  and  complaints  desks 
established to obtain feedback from public users. 
 

c. 

Increase Access to Market-Based Finance 

 
46.  The current problems of a segmented lending market, insufficient institutional capacity for 
MSME  lending,  and  a  lack  of  supporting  infrastructure  (such  as  a  credit  information  system) 
contribute  to  limited  MSME  lending.  While  other  institutions  (namely  BOB  and  BNB)  are 
reluctant  to  expand  their  loan  portfolios  to  MSMEs,  BDFC  also  faces  a  shortage  of  funds, 
despite  its  key  role  in  rural  and  MSME  financing.  It  is  necessary  to  address  BDFC’s  funding 
shortage  and  institutional  capacity  in  MSME  lending  in  order  to  adequately  address  the 
constraints  faced  by  Bhutanese  MSMEs  in  accessing  financing,  in  addition  to  other 
improvement  measures.  The  MSME  SDP  will  therefore  provide  a  credit  line  for  providing 
medium-  and  long-term  finance  to  MSMEs  via  BDFC  (see  the  Project  component)  along  with 
other measures to strengthen BDFC’s performance for improved MSME lending, and to develop 
the  supporting  infrastructure  to  facilitate  the  use  of  collateral,  that  are  essential  for  improving 
market-based finance to MSMEs.

 15 

Restructuring BDFC with Enhanced Capacity Building. It is identified that there is a 
47. 
need for BDFC to strengthen its corporate governance structure, human-resource strategy, and 
other  relevant  MSME  lending  capacity  to  improve  its  operational  efficiency  and  for  better 
services  delivery  to  target  clients.  In  particular,  the  Government  envisages  that  BDFC  will 
continue to play a central role in providing and improving access to finance for micro and small 
enterprises,  especially  in  rural  areas.  To  achieve  such  a  role,  it  is  therefore  recognized  that 
there is a need for BDFC to adopt a new 5-year strategy and business plan which enables it to 
operate  on  a  commercial  basis  for  funding  financially  and  economically  viable  projects.  The 
Program will assist in ensuring the adoption of BDFC’s 5-year strategy and business plan, which 
will  include  a  corporate  governance  structure,  human-resource  strategy,  and  performance 
targets, and be able to further reach out to target clients, especially in rural areas. The technical 
support  necessary  for  preparing  an  adequate  BDFC  business  plan  will  be  delivered  under  an 
ongoing ADB TA 4837  (footnote 16). Skills training in areas of MSME  lending techniques and 
human-resource management will also be provided under the TA 4837. 
 
48. 
Central Registry. To encourage secured transactions and improve the use of collateral, 
the  MSME  SDP  will  set  up  a  central  registry  where  mortgages  and  other  security  interest  in 
moveable  and  immovable  property  can  be  registered  for  use  as  collateral.  A  registry  is  also 
important for monitoring and securing “lender–borrower/creditor-debtor” transactions, facilitating 
credit information sharing, and therefore, effectively improving access to credit by businesses. 
In  view  of  Bhutan’s  small  economy,  a  small  and  cost  effective  central  registry  is  more 
appropriate. Therefore, the Government will establish the central registry at RMA along with the 
ongoing establishment of the credit information bureau (footnote 18). Technical support is to be 
provided under the MSME SDP (under subproject 3) to assist RMA in developing a sound road 
map and action plan for establishing a centralized public registry for secured transactions. In the 
medium term, the MSME SDP will support (i) diagnostic review of the existing legal, regulatory, 
and institutional framework for security interests, including drafting and issuing necessary legal 
amendments  and  implementing  regulations;  (ii)  recommendations  for  establishing  a  central 
system  or  filing  archive  for  registering  collateral  and  security  interests,  including  its  design, 
establishment,  system  requirements,  and  operation  manuals;  and  (iii)  building  awareness 
among banks, businesses, and other stakeholders. 
 
Rationalization  of  Government  Credit  and  Guarantee  Assistance  to  MSMEs. 
49. 
Inasmuch  as  evidence  suggests  that  government  subsidized  programs  and  schemes  may  not 
be particularly effective, the MSME SDP proposes that the Government review its existing two 
credit  and  guarantee  schemes  (i.e.,  the  EDPLS  and  CGS)  with  a  view  to  rationalizing  such 
assistance.  Because  of  the  inherent  negative  impact  of  directing  such  assistance  through  the 
banking  system,  the  assistance  will  more  appropriately  be  directed  through  the  budget,  made 
transparent,  and  have  a  defined  period  of  application  to  achieve  specified  purposes.  After 
review  and  with  sufficient  justification,  the  Government,  in  close  consultation  with  ADB,  after 
review  with  sufficient  justification,  will  adopt  a  coherent  incentive  framework  for  supporting 
MSMEs,  which  will  include  submission  of  plans  to  rationalize  incentive  programs  for  MSMEs 
with increased government reliance on market-based finance for MSME assistance.  
 

d. 

Strengthen Business Support Infrastructure 

 
50. 
Business  Development  Services.  An  important  shift  in  the  thinking  about  BDS  in 
recent years has been that of moving from promoting fully subsidized supply-driven services to 
self-sustaining  demand-driven  services.  In  Bhutan,  there  is  a  potential  commercial  market  for 
BDS. Therefore, to encourage more efficient resource allocation for Government funds and for a 
sustainable,  long-term  strategy  to  develop  human  resources,  the  Government  should  promote 
and  broaden  BDS  support  with  private  sector  participation,  i.e.,  promote  a  commercial  BDS 

 

 the 

market.  The  establishment  of  a  cost-sharing  facility  (CSF)  for  entrepreneurs  and  private  BDS 
start-ups is contemplated under the MSME SDP to provide demand-oriented BDS and meet the 
needs of local entrepreneurs.

important  to  improving  competitiveness  of  products  made  in  Bhutan  and  gaining  access  to

International  Electrotechnical  Commission’s  Affiliate  Country

functions, delegate responsibility, and ensure accountability of SQCA. In view of the increased

systems in Bhutan.

ADF IX Grant 

 
Based  on  the  debt  sustainability  analysis  and  the  revised  Asian  Development  Fund 
53. 
(ADF)  grants  framework,35  Bhutan—with  a  debt-GDP  ratio  of  80%  and  a  debt-exports  ratio  of 
341%—was  classified  as  one  of  the  most  debt-distressed  countries,  and  eligible  for  100%  of 
grant  financing  under  the  high  risk  category  of  debt-distress.  ADF  grants  aim  to  provide 
development  assistance  to  help  the  country  tackle  development  issues  in  an  environment  of 
debt vulnerability, and assist the country in developing the private sector, creating employment

burdens.  The  grant  effectiveness  will  be  assessed  within  the  broader  context  of  program  and 
project  performance.  The  design  of  the  MSME  SDP  and  its  monitoring  framework  has  clear 
indicators to measure the inputs, activities, and outputs (Appendix 3).

The Project 

D. 
 

1. 

Objectives 

 
72. 
The  Project  objective  is  to  provide  the  necessary  investment  and  technical  support  to 
facilitate access to credit by MSMEs and to ensure smooth implementation of the policy reforms 
under  the  MSME  SDP.  The  Project  consists  of  three  subprojects  to  provide  (i)  a  credit  line  to 
BDFC  to  extend  credit  assistance  to  MSMEs,  especially  micro,  small,  and  rural-based 
enterprises;  (ii)  a  CSF  to  provide  the  necessary  technical  support  and  knowledge  transfer  to 
growth-oriented  businesses;  and  (iii)  capacity  support  for  program  implementation  and 
institutional capacity building to ensure the sustainability of the Program and Project and related 
reforms under the MSME SDP.  
 

Components and Outputs 

2. 
 

a. 

Subproject 1: Increase Access to Market-Based Finance  

 
73. 
Based on historical data on credit demand of MSMEs, the market will face a projected 
credit demand of at least $43 million in the period 2008–2010.36 The supply of credit, however, 
is  unlikely  to  meet  the  demand  in  view  of  the  current  problems  of  market  failure,  insufficient 
institutional capacity for MSME lending, and a lack of supporting infrastructure (such as a credit 
information  system).  BDFC,  which  is  keen  to  lend  to  MSMEs,  is  constrained  by  a  shortage  of 
funds  while  other  institutions  (namely,  BOB  and  BNB)  are  reluctant  to  expand  their  loan 
portfolios  to  MSMEs  due  to  a  perceived  higher  credit  risk and  administrative  costs  involved  in 
dealing with small borrowers. Bhutanese MSMEs will continue to suffer from limited finance due 
to BDFC’s funding shortage, and due to insufficient collateral. To help overcome the financing 
constraints  faced  by  MSMEs,  a  credit  line  for  providing  medium-  and  long-term  finance  to 
MSMEs via BDFC, and development of the supporting infrastructure to facilitate credit decision 
making and collateralization, are therefore being pursued under the MSME SDP. 
 
74. 
Credit  Line  to  BDFC  for  MSME  Lending.  Despite  the  fact  that  BDFC  is  the  only 
financial  institution  focusing  on  the  MSME  sector,  particularly  in  rural  areas,  the  need  for  the 
other  two  financial  institutions—BOB  and  BNB—to  provide  medium-  to  long-term  funding  was 
explored.  The  finding  was  that  the  two  financial  institutions  have  increased  their  lending. 
Currently,  only  BOB  has  excess  liquidity,  accounting  for  33%  of  its  total  assets  after  statutory 
liquidity  ratio  requirements  and  cash  reserve  requirements  are  met.37  Therefore,  its  need  for

external  long-term  funding  to  MSMEs  was  low.38  BNB  has  also  extensively  expanded  its  loan

no  interest  in  another  credit  line  from  ADB,  as  the  previous  ADB  project  (footnote  29)  with  a 
credit line was not fully utilized by BNB. Lending has been concentrated in urban areas. 
 
75. 
Pre-identification. As confirmed, BDFC is the only financial institution which has a great 
need  for  funding,  and  is  the  only  financial  institution  interested  in  offering  credit  assistance  to 
MSMEs,  especially  micro  and  small  enterprises.  It  is  also  the  appropriate  agency  to  help 
overcome  the  financial  constraints  of  the  MSME  sector.  BDFC’s  loan  portfolio  growth 
projections for the next 5 years already exceed the organization’s current funding resources. As 
such, to support BDFC in responding adequately to the increasing demand for credit from the 
MSME  sector,  a  credit  line  of  $5  million39  is  proposed.  As  required  by  ADB’s  financial 
intermediary loan modality, other financial aspects of BDFC performance have been reviewed in 
order to assess eligibility. Details are provided in Appendix 6.  
 
76. 
Institutional  Strengthening  and  Capacity-Building  Support  to  BDFC.  To  enable 
BDFC  to  fully  exploit  its  potential  and  effectively  act  as  an  intermediary  in  financing,  it  is 
important  that  BDFC  strengthens  its  structure,  operations,  and  capacity  for  MSME  lending.  In 
particular, BDFC currently has identified the need to (i) review its benefit and incentive structure 
to retain qualified personnel; (ii) adopt a medium- to long-term strategy to address the issue of 
funding  shortage  in,  and  financing  of,  the  MSME  sector;  (iii)  enhance  good  governance, 
including  a  human  resource  development  strategy,  at  the  branch  and  regional  level;  and  (iv) 
ensure  autonomy  of  its  lending  operations.  Therefore,  to  enhance  BDFC’s  efficiency  for  fully 
commercialized operations and its ability to further reach out to target clients (especially in rural 
areas), it is necessary to prepare and adopt an appropriate 5-year strategy and business plan 
that  includes  a  corporate  governance  structure,  human  resource  strategy,  and  performance 
targets.  The  business  plan  will  be  delivered  under  the  ongoing  ADB  TA  4837  (footnote  16)  to 
ensure  that  the  necessary  policies,  procedures,  and  lending  mechanisms,  including  the 
environmental  management  system,  are  in  place  before  disbursement  of  the  credit  line  to 
BDFC.  Relevant  skills  training  in  areas  of  MSME  lending  techniques  and  human  resource 
management will also be provided under the ongoing TA. 

 

Therefore, subproject 1 will provide credit assistance through BDFC to promote MSMEs 
77. 
by  providing  medium-  to  long-term  and  permanent  working  capital  financing  (such  as  stock  of 
spare parts, tools, and raw materials). 
 
Size and Use of the Proposed Credit Line. The proposed size of the credit line is $5 
78. 
million based on the estimate of credit demand from MSMEs and the market share of BDFC in 
MSME  financing  (footnote  39).  The  proposed  credit  line  aims  to  support  the  financing  of  the 
estimated  1,400  additional  MSMEs  entering  the  market  between  2008  and  2010.  The  grant 
proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  new  loans  advanced  by  BDFC,  and  will  not  be  used  to 
refinance the portfolio of old loans or add to the existing portfolio of BDFC.  

                                                 
38 The  financial  institutions  have  been  lending  on  medium-  to  long-term  loans  while  borrowing  on  essentially  short-
term  loans  from  deposits.  As  a  result,  the  maturity  mismatch  in  funds  could  pose  a  major  risk  to  the  stability  of 
these  institutions  as  well  as  to  the  financial  system  as  a  whole  should  sudden  heavy  withdrawal  occur.  The 
financial institutions do not appear to fully recognize this risk, but once they become aware of this mismatch risk, 
the need for, as well as interest in, long-term funding is bound to increase.  

39 The  amount  of  credit  assistance  is  proposed  based  on  the  gap  analysis  (approximately  $43  million)  and  the 
existing market share of BDFC (12%). Consequently, BDFC expects a minimum projected credit demand of around 
$5 million.  

 

  
79. 
Lending.  The  Government  will  receive  $5  million  as  a  grant  from  ADB’s  Special  Fund 
resources under the ADF Grants Program. The grant amount is proposed to be made available 
to BDFC under a loan agreement at the weighted average deposit rate (WADR), published by 
RMA from time to time and prevailing on the date of withdrawal. The WADR will be adjusted at 
three-monthly intervals. The current WADR is estimated at about 3.5% per annum.40 The loan to 
BDFC will have the terms of 20 years maturity including a grace period of 5 years. 
 
Onlending. BDFC will charge the subprojects interest rates based on its cost of funds, 
80. 
plus a spread that covers transaction costs and risk of the subloans. That is, BDFC is expected 
to onlend to economically and financially viable MSMEs at prevailing market rates.  
 
Size of subloans. The maximum size of subloans for individual borrowers is up to Nu2 
81. 
million (about $49,000), with a maximum maturity of 7 years, including a grace period of up to 1 
year,  based  on  the  reasonable  assessment  of  amount  and  maturity  of  credit  demand  by  the 
target  MSMEs.  The  recommendation  will  be  able  to  accommodate  the  existing  loan  profile  of 
BDFC  in  the  growth-oriented  MSMEs  sector  that  ranges  between  Nu100,000  (about  $2,500) 
and  Nu5  million  (about  $125,000)  with  an  average  maturity  of  3  years  and  more  than  73%  of 
loans below Nu2 million. It will be also in line with the historical figures of the average MSME 
loan size of all financial institutions of Nu760,000 (about $18,700), and the envisaged growth of 
loan size.  
 
82. 
Eligibility and Selection Criteria for Subloans. The grant proceeds will be used to (i) 
finance  new  loans  advanced  by  BDFC,  and  will  not  be  used  to  refinance  the  portfolio  of  old 
loans of BDFC, or for housing, equity finance, or staff or personal loans; (ii) finance subprojects 
that  are  economically  and  financially  viable;  and  (iii)  finance  subprojects  that  comply  with  the 
Government’s and ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), except those on the ADB’s exclusion list 
(Supplementary Appendix D). BDFC also will install a basic environmental management system 
(Appendix  7),  with  support  of  the  ongoing  ADB  TA  4837  (footnote  16),  to  screen  the 
environmental impacts of project applications (although no adverse environmental impacts are 
expected from the MSME subprojects to be financed). In addition, MSMEs with an initial capital 
investment, which by definition consists of paid-in capital and long-term credit41 of up to Nu100 
million,  are  eligible.  Subloans  will  be  subject  to  BDFC’s  single  borrower’s  exposure  limit 
according to RMA’s Prudential Regulations (2002) (i.e., no financial institution will extend credit 
to a single borrower exceeding 30% of its capital fund). The selection of MSME subprojects will 
be  based on,  but  not  limited  to,  the  subproject’s  (i)  domestic  demand and  export potential;  (ii) 
potential for development based on competitiveness study, and supply-chain and value-added 
analyses; (iii) factor endowments; and (iv) development impacts.  
 
83. 
Allocation  for  Rural  Women  Entrepreneurs.  In  general,  women  entrepreneurs, 
especially  in  rural  areas,  find  difficulty  in  accessing  finance  in  comparison  with  their  male 
counterparts. Therefore, to facilitate access by women borrowers and improve the livelihood of 
rural  women  (especially  those  who  have  the  ability  to  engage  in  productive  activities),  a 
minimum  of  10%  of  the  credit  line  will  be  allocated  to  lending  to  women  entrepreneurs. 
However,  if  the  allocated  funds  are  not  utilized  within  1.5  years  from  the  date  of  grant 
effectiveness, such funds will revert to the general pool.

84. 
Appraisal and Approval of Subloans (Free Limit). The Project aims to ensure that the 
benefit  of  the  Project  accrues  to  MSMEs,  and,  therefore,  the  subloan  size  is  limited  to  a 
maximum of Nu2 million ($49,000).42 In view of the small-sized subloans and BDFC’s previous 
experiences  with  ADB  under  earlier  loans  (footnote  28),  there  is  no  free  limit  prescribed. 
However, to warrant adequate lending practices of micro and smaller loans for MSMEs, the first 
five micro loans (below Nu50,000) and first three small loans (below Nu100,000) will be referred 
to  ADB  for  approval.  This  is  intended  to  ensure  that  proposed  risk  policies  and  procedures 
based  on  the  recommendations  of  the  ongoing  TA  4837  (footnote  16)  are  adequately 
incorporated into BDFC systems and processes. Subsequently, all subloan applications will be 
subject to post-monitoring and review by ADB. The ongoing TA 4837 will assess the adequacy 
of  the  current  risk  management  system  at  BDFC  and  recommend  appropriate  measures  to 
ensure that the risk management system meets international best practice. Moreover, under the 
ongoing ADB FSDP, the capacity of RMA to supervise the implementation of risk management 
systems  of  financial  institutions  is  being  strengthened.  The  TA  will  also  provide  necessary 
assistance  to  enhance  BDFC’s  lending  capacity,  along  with  the  development  of  a  new  5-year 
strategy  and  business  plan  to  ensure  that  BDFC  efficiently  and  effectively  intermediates 
financing  and  fully  utilizes  the  funds.  BDFC  will  be  required  to  adopt  the  new  strategy  and 
business plan which will be developed by the project preparatory TA team in close consultation 
with the BDFC board, management, and staff, and further approved by BDFC’s board.  
 

b. 

Subproject 2: Enhance Business Development Services 

 
85. 
Subproject 2 will establish a CSF to facilitate demand-oriented private sector BDS and 
MSME start-ups. The function of the CSF is to reduce the cost of external service provision by 
cofinancing  projects  of  successful  applicants  at  a  flat  rate  of  50%  of  the  total  project  cost.  In 
doing so, it increases the utilization of BDS by MSMEs and thus perpetuates the development of 
MSMEs  and  the  market  for  commercial  BDS.  The  CSF  will  support  projects  which  are 
replicable. 
 
86. 
Subproject 2 will run for a period of 4 years. The CSF will operate on a first come, first 
served basis, and will have support from the Government in collaboration with BCCI. As there is 
no  previous  experience  in  Bhutan  with  project-related  grant  facilities,  it  is  recommended  that 
there  is  an  international  consultant  to  assist  in  facility  management  during  its  first  year  of 
operations  for  transferring  facility  management  skills  and  knowledge.  The  consulting  services 
will be financed through subproject 3 and implemented intermittently over the first and second 
years of CSF operations.  
 
87. 
Institutional  Arrangement  of  the  CSF.  A  CSF  management  unit  will  be  set  up  and 
integrated  with  the  MSME  division  in  order  to  reduce  the  overhead  costs  of  the  facility.  The 
management  unit  will  be  responsible  for  marketing,  undertaking  project  analysis,  financial 
management,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  will  be  accountable  to  MTI.  The  unit  will 
employ  three  local  staff  from  the  public  sector  and  public  sector  institutions.  The  Government

to support management of the CSF under subproject 2. If no eligible people are found, one or

management unit to ensure adequate and efficient use of funds.  
 
88. 
Approval. A five-member appraisal panel will be appointed, comprising representatives 
from MTI, MOA, BDFC, and the private sector. Its function is to review the CSF grant proposals 
recommended  by  the  CSF  management  unit.  The  unit  manager  of  the  CSF  management  unit 
will be a full voting member of the appraisal panel. A quorum of three members will be required 
to approve applications, by majority vote if necessary. Grants should only be approved where a 
long-term  strategic  benefit  is  projected.  The  source  of  the  applicant’s  contribution  may  be 
through the owners’ own funds, or through bank loans or equity participation, or a combination 
of  these.  The  appraisal  panel,  when  approving  applicants  for  CSF  grants,  will  ensure  wide 
dispersion of funds. 
 
89. 
Eligible  Applicants.  The  main  target  group  for  grants  will  be  MSMEs  which  have  a 
paid-in  capital  below  Nu100  million.  Private  individual  MSMEs,  recognized  groups  of  MSMEs, 
individual business service providers, or recognized groups of service providers are eligible for 
applying for the cost sharing grant. Only domestically owned MSMEs or service providers will be 
eligible.  Parastatals,  government  entities,  and  other  MSMEs  or  service  providers  where  the 
government or its agencies have management control by virtue of being the largest shareholder 
or of having a board majority, will not be eligible. Any conflict of interest shall also render such 
applicants ineligible, such as a relationship with any of the Government officials involved in the 
implementation  of  the  CSF  within  the  immediate  family.  The  CSF  supports  group  activities 
covering  more  than  one  MSME  or  service  provider  (such  as  those  sponsored  by  business  or 
trade associations, BCCI, or organized clusters) where the benefits are widespread. Where an 
application is made on a group basis, it will be evaluated and processed as a single application. 
 
90. 
Selection Criteria for Projects. The following criteria will be applied to select projects 
supported by the CSF: (i) the projects must be economically and financially viable; (ii) projects 
must  comply  with  the  Government’s  and  ADB’s  Environment  Policy,43  (iii)  eligible  projects, 
except  those  on  ADB’s  exclusion  list  (Supplementary  Appendix  D),  will  include,  but  not  be 
limited to, sectors that (a) have domestic demand and export potential; (b) factor endowments; 
and (c) potential for development of MSMEs based on competitiveness study, and supply-chain 
and  value-added  analyses;  (iv)  projects  which  are  replicable,  and  (v)  projects  with  high 
development impacts.

Eligible  Expenditures.  Expenditures  on  service  fees,  and  expenditures  on  travel  and

c. 

Subproject  3:  Program  Implementation  and  Institutional  Capacity 
Building 

 
94. 
Subproject 3 will provide technical advice and resources needed to support and facilitate 
program  implementation.  In  particular,  capacity  building  and  institutional  development  will  be 
crucial  for  conducting  certain  policy  actions  and  facilitating  crucial  project  implementation  for 
MSME  development.  The  components  of  subproject  3  are  discussed  as  follows.  Terms  of 
reference for subproject 3 are in Supplementary Appendix E.  
 
95. 
Component  1:  Formulation  of  MSME  Development  Strategy  and  Support  of  the 
CSF Management. This component will assist the PSDC (or such body as may be designed for 
the  purpose  through  the  MSME  division  at  MTI)  in  formulating  a  coordinated  MSME 
development  policy,  strategy  and  institutional  framework,  and  MSME  development  program.  It 
will do this by conducting (and accessing existing) competitiveness studies of various products 
and  services  in  order  to  identify  and  prioritize  specific  agro-  and  strategic  industries  and 
products.  It  will  also  prepare  cluster  and  supply-chain  analyses  to  determine  weak  links  and 
areas  for  assistance.  The  technical  support  will  be  conducted  in  close  consultation  with  the 
private sector, e.g., BCCI and stakeholders.  
 
96. 
Component 1 will also provide technical support to management of the CSF in (i) setting 
up procedures, (ii) establishing eligibility criteria for MSMEs and service providers, (iii) designing 
data  collection  and  monitoring  systems,  (iv)  processing  and  appraising  applications,  and  (v)
