and  knowledge, 
including  grant  scheme  management,  human-resource  development, 
marketing, and monitoring and evaluation, will be transferred to the domestic CSF manager and 
other staff in the facility.  
 
97. 
Component  2:  Capacity  Building  for  Introduction  of  RIA.  This  component  will 
provide  technical  support  and  resources  needed  for  regulators  and  staff  in  the  RIA  working 
group  to  build  capacity  and  to  pilot  RIAs.  This  component  includes  conducting  necessary 
stakeholder  workshops,  consultations,  and  training  modules  (including  on-the-job  training 
measures and study tours) for RIA implementers.  
 
98. 
Component  3:  Establishment  of  a  Central  Registry.  Component  3  will  support  the 
establishment  and  implementation  of  a  central  registry  at  RMA.  This  component  includes 
preparation  of  a  feasibility  study,45  including  identification  and  drafting  of  the  necessary  legal 
and  regulatory  framework,  costing  of  appropriate  hardware  and  software  equipment,  and 
preparation  of  request  for  proposal  for  procurement  of  consulting  services  and  equipment. 
Currently, RMA is considering a two-phased approach. The first phase will create a preliminary 
database which lists existing collateralized properties recorded with the financial institutions. It 
will also involve the input of consultancy services for preparing an establishment plan, including 
recommendations on the legal framework, legislation, and equipment needed to consolidate all 
the registration information including immovable properties and also allowing for registration of 
movable  assets.  The  second  phase  will  subsequently  implement  the  establishment  plan, 
arrange links and networks, and make the central registry fully operational. 
 
99. 
Component  4:  Planning  the  Establishment  of  Product  Standards  and  Capacity 
Building.  This  component  will  assist  in  reviewing  the  legal  framework  and  developing  the 
organizational arrangement of the new Bhutan Standards Bureau (a national standards body as 
envisaged  in  the  Good  Governance  Plus  2005  paper  and  the  upcoming  Standards  Act). 
Component  4  will  also  assess  and  recommend  the  division  of  tasks  between  the  various 
participants  in  the  new  standards  and  control  system.  This  component  will  assist  in  (i)  the 
elaboration of phased and prioritized action, (ii) assessment for laboratory needs not covered by 
the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, (iii) estimation of additional equipment 
costs,  (iv)  assessment  of  staff  requirements,  and  (v)  the  development  of  a  human-resources 
development plan and costs.  
 
100.  Component 4 will pay particular attention to the institution building of BAFRA, as quality 
improvements  in  food  value  chains  are  a  priority  for  MSME  development  in  Bhutan.  As  the 
present staff numbers and qualifications do not allow BAFRA to satisfactorily fulfill its tasks in a 
growing market, there is a need to build capacity within BAFRA in the discharge of its specific 
functions.

105.  Disbursement Arrangements. The Project grants will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time). To ensure timely 
release of ADB funds for eligible expenditures, two imprest accounts will be established at RMA, 
one for each IA. The first imprest account (for BDFC) will finance all activities under subproject 1 
subject  to  executing  of  the  loan  agreements  in  place  between  BDFC  and  the  Government 
acceptable  to  ADB.  The  second  imprest  account  (for  MTI)  will  finance  all  activities  under 
subprojects 2 and 3. The Division of Debt Management at the Public Accounts Department of 
MOF will be responsible for managing the imprest account and ensuring timely release of funds. 
The  combined  initial  advance  to  the  imprest  accounts  will  be  for  6  months  of  estimated 
expenditures  or  10%  of  the  Project  grant  amount,  whichever  is  lower.  The  statement  of 
expenditure  procedure  may  be  used  for  reimbursing  eligible  expenditures  and  liquidating 
advances to the imprest accounts for any individual payment not exceeding $50,000.  
 
106.  The Project grant will be available for 4 years, particularly considering the disbursement 
schedule of the credit line to BDFC (Subproject 1) and the CSF (Subproject 2). In addition, for 
subproject 1, BDFC will recycle the funds for new subloans after the earlier approved subloans 
are paid off. Lending by the Government to BDFC will be a fixed period of 20 years, inclusive of 
a 5-year grace period. 
 
107.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting. The PPMU will maintain separate records and 
accounts for the imprest accounts in accordance with sound accounting principles and will have 
these accounts and records audited annually in accordance with standards acceptable to ADB. 
Audited accounts, including statement of expenditures, will be provided to ADB within 6 months 
of fiscal year end. ADB retains the right to (i) audit any account, and (ii) verify the validity of the 
certification issued by the Government for each withdrawal application. The audit will provide an 
opinion on the imprest accounts and statement of expenditure operations.

108.  The  PPMU  will  submit  reports  to  ADB  concerning  the  use  of  project  grant  proceeds, 
project  administration,  and  financial  management.  The  reports  will  include  (i)  6-monthly  and 
annual project implementation reports, (ii) a midterm review report, and (iii) a project completion 
report  to  be  submitted  no  later  than  6  months  after  project  completion.  The  reports  and 
consolidating  inputs  from  the  IAs  will  cover  (i)  expenditures,  (ii)  activities  financed,  (iii)  a 
summary of audit issues, and (iv) the progress of project components. 
 
109.  The  consultants  recruited  under  the  Project  grant  will  prepare  (i)  an  inception  report 
within  1  month  of  service  commencement;  (ii)  midterm  reports  at  appropriate  stages  of  the 
Project;  (iii)  a  draft  final  report  2  weeks  before  completing  the  contract;  and  (iv)  a  final  report 
after incorporating comments from ADB, the EA, and the IAs. A tripartite meeting between the 
Government,  ADB,  and  the  consultants  will  be  carried  out  prior  to  the  finalization  of  each 
undertaking and the termination of each contract.   
 
110.  ADB has assessed the financial management capacity of the EA and IAs and found that 
in  general  the  EA  and  IAs  are  satisfactory  at  a  program  and  project  level  (see  paras.  62–66). 
However,  since  MTI  has  no  prior  ADB  project  management  experience,  MTI  representatives 
responsible  for  project  implementation  will  undergo  a  project  implementation  training  and 
workshop  in  enhancing  institutional  capacity  and  project  management  prior  to  undertaking 
actual project implementation under the MSME SDP.   
 
111.  Project  Performance  Monitoring  and  Evaluation.  The  PPMU,  drawing  on  data  from 
IAs, will establish and maintain a project performance management system that will generate 6-
monthly  and  annual  reports.  The  system  will  be  linked  with  the  Program  and  established,  as 
agreed between the Government and ADB, to ensure that (i) the Project is managed efficiently, 
(ii)  benefits  are  maximized,  and  (iii)  environmental  and  social  impacts  are  minimized  and 
mitigated.  
 
112.  Project  Review.  The  Government  and  ADB  will  periodically 
review  project 
implementation.  ADB  will  field  regular  review  missions,  including  midterm  and  project 
completion  review  missions  to  coincide  whenever  possible  with  the  program  reviews.  A 
comprehensive midterm review at approximately 18 months from the date of grant effectiveness 
will  be  undertaken  to  evaluate  progress.  These  reviews  will  include  (i)  an  evaluation  of  the 
project  scope,  (ii)  implementation  arrangements,  (iii)  a  review  of  environmental  management 
system  (EMS)  performance  at  BDFC  and  environmental  due  diligence  at  the  CSF,  and  (iv) 
progress with the policy reform agenda. 
 
113.  Anticorruption. In conformity with the recommendations of ADB’s Second Governance 
and  Anticorruption  Action  Plan,47  which  specifies  that  program  and  project  design  should 
incorporate  findings  of  governance,  institutional,  and  corruption  risk  assessments,  and  that 
project  documentation  should  clearly  identify  risk  and  risk-management  and  mitigation 
measures. The summary of the findings is as follows.  
 
114.  Many  funding  agencies’  reports  on  sectoral  assessments  indicated  that  the  Bhutanese 
public sector is relatively free of systemic institutional corruption.48 A proxy measure49 to analyze 
the  level  of  corruption  in  the  public  sector  indicates  a  generally  decreasing  trend  in  assessed 

                                                 
47 ADB. 2006. Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II). Manila. 
48  For  example,  the  World  Bank  has  stated  that  the  Government  has  “a  long-standing  reputation  for  honesty  and 

professionalism”. (World Bank. 2004. Bhutan Country Brief. Washington, DC). 

49  The measure looks at total amounts cited by RAA audits that are due to the Government from public sector bodies 

for expenditures unallowable under existing Government rules (e.g., the Financial Rules and Regulations). 

 

 unallowed  expense  amounts  based  on  RAA’s  audits.50  Recently,  RAA  has  become  more 
aggressive in fulfilling its functions as a result of the extended mandate due to the enactment of 
the Audit Act (2006) as well as improved staffing and capacity. Therefore, RAA is more likely to 
find instances of misuse of public funds than before. However, total monetary irregularities have 
been  reduced  significantly  as  compared  with  earlier  annual  reports;  irregularities  were  about 
Nu264,208 million in 2005, down from Nu369,339 million in 2004. Even though there has been 
no system-wide corruption assessments or analyses conducted to date, it is fair to conclude that 
Bhutan has a low risk of systemwide and institutionalized corruption in the public sector. 
 
115.  The  Government  has  taken  serious  steps  to  prevent  corruption.  Anticorruption  policy 
actions include (i) the drafting of an anticorruption law designed to help detect, prosecute, and 
punish perpetrators of any corrupt practices;51 (ii) encouraging the incorporation of legal units in 
every public body to address legal issues and strengthening internal audit of departments; (iii) 
revising  procedures  for  procuring  goods,  awarding  contracts,  bidding,  and  licensing;  (iv) 
instituting a zero-tolerance approach to raise the risks corrupt elements face; and (v) instituting 
a  system  in  which  an  audit  clearance  certificate  is  a  prerequisite  for  each  staff  member’s 
promotion,  training,  and  contract  extension.  Bhutan  has  been  progressing  in  adopting  the 
following  anticorruption  policies:  (i)  the  Anticorruption  Act  (2006)  has  been  enacted;  (ii)  the 
Government,  with  ADB’s  assistance,  is  in  the  process  of  strengthening  the  anti-money 
laundering and combating financial terrorism regime by (a) enhancing the legal framework, (b) 
instituting  the  financial  intelligence  unit,  and  (c)  establishing  a  reporting  and  monitoring 
procedure  for  recording  and  investigating  suspicious  financial  transactions  (supported  by  the 
FSDP);  and  (iii)  the  RAA,  an  autonomous  body  which  conducts  all  types  of  audits  on  all 
government  agencies, 
institutions,  nongovernment 
organizations, and externally funded projects, has adopted the performance audit as part of the 
overall audit approach to look at the use of public resources for, and the impact on the people 
of, an integrated report on the economic, efficient, and effective use of public funds.  
 
116.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Project or the MSME SDP. To 
support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  are  included  in  the 
grant regulations and the bidding documents for the Project. In particular, all contracts financed 
by ADB in connection with the Project will include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit 
and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  EA  and  IAs,  and  all  contractors,  suppliers, 
consultants,  and  other  service  providers  as  they  relate  to  the  Project.  During  regular  review 
missions, governance and anticorruption risk assessments will be updated as necessary.

IV. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
117.  Benefits.  The  MSME  SDP  is  expected  to  contribute  to  inclusive  growth  in  Bhutan  by 
promoting  the  development  of  the  MSME  sector  (and  thereby  the  private  sector),  through  an 
integrated  and  comprehensive  strategic  approach  to  MSME  development,  an  enhanced 
business  environment,  improved  access  to  credit  by  MSMEs  through  a  financially  stronger

BDFC  with  enhanced  institutional  capacity  and  outreach  and  better  use  of  security  and  credit 
information;  and  increased  BDS  for  enterprises  to  access  training,  technology,  marketing,  and 
information. As a whole, MSMEs are expected to benefit from the holistic approach adopted by 
the MSME SDP to have (i) an enabling policy and regulatory environment for doing business, (ii) 
better  access  to  financing,  (iii)  enhanced  business  support  infrastructure,  and  (iv)  increased 
market  access  and  product  competitiveness  for  sustainable  economic  growth.  It  is  estimated 
that more than 1,400 enterprises will gain access to finance for business expansion and at least 
250 enterprises will receive training and technical support, on a cost-sharing basis, during the 
project implementation period.  
 
118.  Furthermore,  due  to  the  improved  connectivity  and  accessibility  in  rural  areas  and 
between urban and rural areas achieved by the East-West National Highway project (footnote 
29) supported by ADB’s projects, the focus of the MSME SDP on micro and small enterprises, 
including rural enterprises, is envisaged to enhance employment opportunities for the poor and 
improve  the  livelihood  of  rural  people.  The  benefits  of  the  micro  and  small  business 
development  on  the  livelihood  of  rural  people  will  have  incidental  effects  on  other  aspects  of 
their  lives,  such  as  education,  health,  and  service  delivery,  due  to  the  joint  impact  of  higher 
incomes  and  better  access  to  markets.  In  addition,  the  business  expansion  by  MSMEs  and 
enhanced private sector growth will further help absorb the increasing numbers of young people 
and recent graduates entering the labor force and broaden the base for economic activities. The 
involved  agencies  and  institutions  are  also  expected  to  benefit  from  the  institutional 
strengthening and capacity development under the Project, which will enhance their operational 
and administrative efficiency and effectiveness for MSME development.  
 
Impacts. The MSME SDP is classified environmental category FI as it involves a credit 
119. 
line through BDFC. The credit line involves only small loans (see para. 81). In addition, BDFC’s 
subloans to MSMEs will be largely in the sectors of trade and services, tourism, transport (light 
vehicle)  and  agro-processing;  none  will  be  in  infrastructure.  It  is  unlikely  that  significant 
environmental impacts, involuntary resettlement, or negative impacts on indigenous people will 
occur. The social and poverty impact of the MSME SDP is in Appendix 10.  
 
120.  To  further  ensure  no  adverse  environmental  impact  occurs  as  a  result  of  project 
implementation,  the  eligibility  criteria  for  subloans  will  comply  with  the  government  and  ADB's 
safeguard policies and will be enhanced through BDFC's implementation of the EMS (Appendix 
7) prepared in accordance with applicable environmental requirements of the Government and 
of ADB. Similarly, the eligibility criteria for MSMEs applying for grants under the CSF includes 
compliance  with,  or  commitment  to  comply  with,  Government  and  ADB  environmental 
requirements. In addition, BDFC is advised not to lend to companies in the exclusion list (see 
Supplementary Appendix D), and will report any violation or noncompliance by their borrowers 
with  health,  safety,  and  environmental  regulations  to  ensure  that  the  onlending  by  BDFC 
adheres to ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and that there is no adverse impact from subloans 
financed  from  the  credit  line.  ADB  will  also  provide  necessary  training,  including  design  of  a 
basic  EMS,  to  BDFC  under  the  ongoing  TA  4387  (footnote  16)  and  the  CSF  at  MTI  under 
subproject 3, to further strengthen its institutional capacity for environmental safeguards.  
 
121.  Risks and Mitigating Measures. Three categories of possible risks can be expected for 
the MSME SDP: (i) policy reversal, (ii) program and/or project implementation and coordination 
risks among involved agencies, and (iii) institutional capacity of project implementing agencies. 
The MSME SDP has incorporated mitigating measures as appropriate and possible to attenuate 
the impacts associated with the risks.  
 

 

 122.  The  first  category  of  possible  risks  involved  during  program  implementation  is  the 
slowing-down  of  policy  momentum.  This  is  emphasized  in  Bhutan  because  of  the  impending 
transition  of  the  country  into  a  parliamentary  democracy  by  2008.  However,  given  the 
conservative and traditionalist view of the voting population and political parties, a parliamentary 
democracy  is  likely  to  enhance  rather  than  impede  the  broad-based  ownership  of  the  reform 
actions, and policies adopted by the present regime are expected to continue. In addition, the 
new  parliament  is  expected  to  be  filled  with  representatives  not  only  with  the  requisite 
experience but also the qualifications needed to respond to the new challenges facing Bhutan 
during modernization. In addition, as the Government has established a private sector working 
group  to  assist  in  the  formulation  of  the  next  midterm  development  strategy  (the  Tenth  Five-
Year  Plan52),  this  indicates  a  continuous  important  role  for  MSME  development  in  economic 
growth in the next 5 years. Therefore, the Government is expected to remain committed to the 
reform  agenda  undertaken  by  the  MSME  SDP  to  promote  the  MSME  sector,  ensuring  private 
enterprise participation in the growth process. 
 
123.  The  activities  and  policy  reforms  for  MSME  development  involve  multiple  sectors  and 
work  across  ministries.  Therefore,  a  lack  of  close  coordination  among  relevant  government 
agencies to support and oversee program and project implementation is the second category of 
possible risk to the success of the MSME SDP. To mitigate such coordination failure, the MSME 
SDP  will  ensure  smooth  implementation  through  an  adequate  institutional  mechanism  at  two 
levels: a PSC at the interministerial level, and a dedicated MSME division at the implementation 
level.  In  addition,  to  ensure  a  participatory  consultative  process  and  public-private  partnership 
for  providing  necessary  checks  and  balances,  the  MSME  SDP  will  have  private  sector 
representation,  through  the  inclusion  of  private  sector  representatives  and  their  active 
participation  in  the  MSME  division  through  the  BCCI,  in  order  to  contribute  and  provide 
feedback on program and project implementation.

MSME  Sectoral  Distribution.  Official  statistics  refer  to  the  number  of  licenses.  However, 
businesses with one identification number may hold more than one license; therefore, taking one 
identification  number  as  an  indication  of  one  operational  business,  in  2006,  there  was  a  total  of 
16,823 businesses (including in the trade industry) operating in Bhutan. Of these, around 98% of 
the registered businesses are in the categories of MSMEs, illustrating the prevalence of MSMEs in 
Bhutan (Table A1.2). The percentage of MSMEs in each sector only differs slightly. In the service 
and  trade  sector,  more  than  98%  of  operating  businesses  are  MSMEs,  while  in  the  construction, 
manufacturing and energy sector, the percentage goes down slightly, to 96%.

3. 
Geographical  Distribution.  In  terms  of  geographical  distribution,  most  businesses  are 
concentrated in the western area of Bhutan, including Thimphu, Paro, and the bordering Wangdue 
Phodrang  (45%).  A  significant  number  of  businesses  are  concentrated  at  the  foothills  of  the 
Himalaya  along  the  Indian  border  in  the  (southern)  districts  of  Chhuka,  Samtse,  Sarpang,  and 
Samdrup  Jongkhar  (29%).  Finally,  there  are  some  businesses  in  the  eastern  central  districts, 
including Trashigang, Mongar, and Bumthang along the central lateral road (12%).

B.  Sector Analysis for MSME Development 
 
4. 
The  Bhutanese  economy  is  basically  centered  on  subsistence  agriculture.  The  agriculture 
sector  (including  mining)  employs  approximately  45%  of  the  total  labor  force  but  contributes 
relatively  little  to  overall  sector  growth  (only  1.2%  in  2005).  The  industry  sector  (including 
manufacturing,  hydropower,  and  construction)  accounted  for  2.6%  of  sector  growth  but  engages 
only about 16.1% of the total labor force. The services and trade sector grew the fastest at 13.3%, 
and  employs  19.5%  of  the  total  labor  force,  contributing  the  most  to  real  gross  domestic  product 
(GDP)  growth  in  2005.  As  evident,  in  terms  of  employment  importance,  the  agriculture  sector 
represents  the  key  economic  activity  of  the  country;  nonetheless,  the  relative  low  contribution  to 
overall GDP growth underlines hidden unemployment and low productivity. On the other side, the 
importance of industry (especially manufacturing), the services, and trade sectors is underscored 
by  their  apparent  growth  potential  and  their  looming  importance  for  job  creation  and  for  broad-
based economic development.  
 
5. 
products in each sector, which is particularly relevant to MSME development.  

The  following  sections  provide  a  sector  analysis  and  illustrations  of  potential  growth 

 

1. 

Agriculture Sector 

 
 
The  agriculture  sector,  which  comprises  agriculture  proper,  livestock  production,  forestry, 
6. 
logging,  mining,  and  quarrying,  had  a  GDP  share  of  about  23.8%  in  2005,  down  from  24.7%  in 
2004.  It  employed  about  60%  of  the  total  labor  force  in  2004  and  44.7%  in  2005,  and  is  a  key 
source  of  livelihood  for  most  Bhutanese  people.  However,  the  growth  of  agricultural  productivity 
has been limited due to the difficult terrain, poor soil quality, and limited availability of cultivatable 
land,  which  is  approximately  7.7%  of  the  total  land  area.  In  addition,  lack  of  market  access  is 
another major reason why farmers are reluctant to produce a crop surplus beyond what is required 
for  barter  transactions.  Despite  facing  constraints  of  production  enhancement,  the  agriculture 
sector is slowly shifting to cash-crop production, such as fruit and vegetables, as these offer more 
viable  sources  of  income  as  these  products  enjoy  seasonal  advantages  and  large  markets  in 
neighboring countries such as Bangladesh and India.  
 
Under  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan,  a  total  of  41,300  farmers  were  trained  in  cash-crop 
7. 
cultivation and 225 kilometers (km) of farm roads were constructed to improve access to markets. 
Due to Bhutan’s landlocked and mountainous geographic location and poor access to the rest of 
the world via sea and air routes, only high-value products or those enjoying seasonal comparative 
advantage are able to overcome the disadvantage of high transport costs for exports. These have 
been largely confined to tree crops, vegetables, and spices. Three commercially significant crops 
are oranges and areca nuts in the subtropics and apples in the temperate areas. Altogether, they 
account for 96% of the horticultural trees planted and 92% of total production.  
 
8. 
Domestic  and  Export  Market.  With  respect  to  domestic  demand,  imported  produce  is 
increasing  as  urban  populations  grow  and  tastes  move  to  higher-value  products.  Although  the 
large  markets  in  India  and  Bangladesh  can  absorb  all  that  Bhutan  can  produce,  limited  land  and 
the  huge  variety  of  microclimates1  have  constrained  the  establishment  of  large-scale  farming. 
Agricultural exports include oranges, apples, potatoes, cardamom, ginger, chilies, vegetables, and 
processed  fruit  products,  and  the  destinations  of  exports  include  India,  Bangladesh,  Singapore, 

                                                 
1  A microclimate refers to a local atmospheric zone where the climate differs from the surrounding area. The term may 
refer to areas as small as a few square feet (for example a garden bed) or as large as many square miles (for example 
a valley). One of the contributing factors to microclimate is the slope or aspect, which is the case in Bhutan. 

 

 Appendix 1 

37 

and  Japan.  Exports  to  countries  other  than  India  and  Bangladesh  could  be  increased  with  the 
introduction of product certification and use of international standards. 
 
9. 
Constraints. While agriculture is turning more to cash-crop production and the contribution 
of tree crops has been increasing in recent years, the share of the total agricultural sector to GDP 
is  decreasing.  This  is  due  to  the  decreasing  contribution  of  cereals,  livestock,  and  food  crop 
production  as  a  result  of  natural  causes  and  the  specialization  brought  about  by  free  trade  with 
India.  In  view  of  the  good  potential  for  food  crops  to  be  cultivated  in  the  agro-ecological  zones,2 
improved  seeds  and  management  practices  are  necessary  to  develop  the  agro-industry  through 
exports of low-volume, high-value products in a favorable environment like Bhutan.  
 
10. 
Target Industries and Products with Growth Potential. Bhutan’s comparative advantage 
in the agricultural sector derives from its wide range of microclimatic conditions (i.e., many valleys 
with different altitudes and/or slopes) that allows cultivation of a large variety of produce. Coupled 
with the fact that its neighbors are mainly tropical agricultural producers and that Bhutan is able to 
produce temperate zone crops 1 month later than its neighbors, Bhutan is virtually the only source 
of supply for fresh produce during certain periods of the year in the region. As such, Bhutan has 
great potential in two areas: (i) in low-volume, high-value products aiming at niche markets based 
on  comparative  advantages  such  as  the  range  of  microclimates,  biodiversity,  and  organic 
production;  niche-crop  production  could  include  essential  oils,  traditional  medicines,  mushrooms, 
and incense; and (ii) in larger-scale, foreign-investment businesses in border areas based on the 
comparative  advantages  of  flexible  labor,  a  stable  political  environment,  and  competitive 
infrastructure, predominantly using imported raw materials. To exploit this potential, firms will need 
(i)  access  to  competitive,  consistent,  and  high-quality  raw  materials  in  a  timely  manner;  (ii) 
supportive policies on transport, labor, and investment; (iii) an innovative approach to productions, 
processes,  packaging,  and  product  marketing;  and  (iv)  improved  productivity  through  better 
management  and  enhanced  labor  skills.  In  addition,  forward  linkages  of  products  (e.g.,  supply 
chains) should be fully explored.  
 
 
 
11. 
In 2005, the industry sector as a whole accounted for 34.4% of overall GDP. Specifically, 
the manufacturing sector contributed 7.3% of GDP, hydropower 10%, and construction 17%. Total 
employment of the construction and hydropower sectors amounts to 14.1% of the total labor force, 
while  the  manufacturing  sector  engages  only  2%.  However,  as  most  construction  projects  are 
hydropower-related,  and  as  these  have  gradually  been  completed,  the  construction  sector  has 
shown  signs  of  negative  growth  in  2005.  In  addition,  due  to  the  low  employment  elasticity  (i.e., 
sensitivity of growth of employment with respect to sector growth) of the hydropower sector and the 
relative  unwillingness  of  Bhutanese  to  participate  in  the  construction  sector,  it  is  imperative  that 
economic activity is diversified by promoting private sector activity, especially in the MSME-related 
sectors, such as the manufacturing and service sectors.  
 
12. 
Bhutan’s manufacturing sector is still small, technologically backward, and state dominated. 
Most private businesses are small or cottage enterprises. The Bhutanese manufacturing industries 
are  highly  dependent  on  processing  primary  products  with  low  value  adding,  such  as  food 

Industry Sector  

2. 

                                                 
2  Agro-ecological  zones  are  defined  based  on  the  combinations  of  soil,  landform  and  climatic  characteristics.  The 
particular  parameters  used  in  the  definition  focus  on  the  climatic  and  soil  requirements  of  crops  and  on  the 
management  systems  under  which  the  crops  are  grown.  Each  zone  has  a  similar  combination  of  constraints  and 
potentials for land use, and serves as a focus for the targeting of recommendations designed to improve the existing 
land-use situation, either through increasing production or by limiting land degradation. The Ministry of Agriculture has 
released 25 improved varieties of rice, wheat, maize, and oilseeds. In the past, high-altitude areas like Bumthang could 
only grow buckwheat, wheat, and barley, but rice cultivation has now begun using high-altitude varieties. 

 38 

Appendix 1 

processing,  sawmills,  distillery,  and  furniture-making.  The  main  products  include  liquors,  agro-
based edible items, stranded wire, cables, plaited bands of copper, base metals or metal products 
(such  as  iron,  steel,  coins,  and  kitchenware),  and  mineral  products  (such  as  mineral  oils  and 
cement).  Other  manufactured  goods  available  in  the  domestic  market  are  mostly  imported  from 
neighboring countries. Due to the inadequate industrial environment and infrastructure, the lack of 
skill  and  technology,  and  the  high  cost  of  production,  activities  in  the  manufacturing  sector  have 
been very limited. 
 
13. 
The  manufacturing  sector  in  Bhutan  is  dominated  by  agro,  mineral,  and  wood-based 
industries. In the agro-processing industry, Bhutan produces a narrow range of fresh produce and 
a  smaller  range  of  processed  food  products  in  a  very  few  product  categories.  In  2000,  fruit 
processing contributed over 90% to employment in the manufacturing sector—excluding alcoholic 
beverages. The relatively unorganized food-processing sector is dominated by small firms—none 
of  which  are  foreign  owned—comprising  99  micro  and  small  enterprises,  nine  medium-sized 
enterprises, and nine large enterprises as of 2006.  
 
Domestic  and  Export  Market.  The  market  for  agro-processing  and  food  products 
14. 
produced by small enterprises is mainly local. There are only some large food processors who sell 
over  65%  of  their  production  to  India,  a  small  amount  to  Bangladesh,  and  the  remainder  locally. 
For the mineral industry, the processed minerals are mainly exported to India and other countries 
for use as inputs in higher value-added goods. For wood and wood products, the domestic market 
is fragmented; one is for individuals in rural areas for construction of private houses and the other 
is for commercial construction funded by the Government or donors for large hydropower projects 
or for the renovation of temples. The export market for wood and wooden products is very limited, 
because since 1999 the Government has banned all export of logs, sawn wood, and semifinished 
products.  
 
15. 
Constraints.  In  the  agro-processing  and  food-processing  sectors,  impediments  to 
competitiveness are at the front of the value chain, including the cost, availability, and reliability of 
raw  materials  delivered  to  the  processors.  The  relative  efficiency  in  financing,  manufacturing, 
packaging, branding, marketing, and distribution, as well as the overall business environment, are 
constraints  to  further  developing  the  sector.  Specifically,  scale,  modern  processing,  management 
systems, and brand awareness are critical factors that Bhutanese processors will need to address 
for product development. Realistically, Bhutan’s role will only be as a niche market player. In spite 
of  the  lucrative  future  of  niche  markets,  Bhutan  is  apparently  having  difficulty  penetrating  these 
niche markets, which are price-sensitive to product quality.  
 
16. 
Target  Industries  and  Products  with  Growth  Potential.  In  view  of  the  small  scale  of 
agro-production in Bhutan, Bhutanese enterprises have to identify specialty and niche products for 
smaller  markets.  Organic  produce  is  identified  as  such.  In  fact,  much  of  the  farming  system  in 
Bhutan is organic, but this advantage has not been leveraged because of a lack of awareness of 
organic farming systems, infrastructure, marketing facilities, access to capital, and ability to capture 
economies  of  scale.  The  major  hurdles  to  be  overcome  include  high  certification  costs,  lack  of 
market information and marketing strategies, insufficient export facilitation, complex procedures in 
importing  countries,  and  tariff  and  nontariff  protection  in  import  markets.  Certification  and 
accreditation are especially important for this sector, because in most cases exporters depend on 
certification  by  international  certification  bodies  to  be  able  to  market  their  products  as  organic  in 
foreign markets. Costs of certification vary but can be significant. Despite the difficulty that Bhutan 
may have in establishing a national certification infrastructure, it is imperative to start the planning 
of  establishing  a  certification  and  accreditation  system  for  sustainable  development  in  the  agro-
based or food-processing industry.

39 

3. 

Service and Trade Sector 

17. 
Given  the  range  of  microclimates  and  extent  of  biodiversity,  high-value,  low-volume 
products  such  as  essential  oils  and  those  that  can  be  used  as  traditional  medicines  represent 
another  potential  growth  area.  Bhutan  has  a  further  advantage  in  producing  a  full  range  of 
products, both high- and low-altitude species; however, an apparent lack of technology and skills 
severely handicaps the development of these high-value products.  
 
18. 
Another product with export potential is handicrafts, including wooden handicrafts (including 
wooden statuettes, wooden caskets, basketware, vegetable plaiting material and plaiting material, 
and incense), natural dyes, and handwoven textiles. For this type of product, exporters can target a 
large number of common markets. There are two potential advantages: (i) to develop further new 
markets  not  currently  supplied  by  other  exporters  of  wooden  handicrafts,  and  (ii)  to  work  within 
existing  markets  by  distinguishing  Bhutanese  products  under  the  “Bhutan”  brand.  Major  markets 
could  include  the  United  States,  Switzerland,  or  other  European  countries,  including  tourists  that 
visit those countries. 
 
19. 
The Government has adopted a restrictive policy in the timber and wood-based industry. To 
further  develop  wood-based  products,  there  is  a  need  to  review  whether  sustainable  forest 
management  could  supply  both  the  domestic  and  export  markets  for  wood  in  order  to  move 
towards a future in which the environmental impact could be minimized and the demand for wood 
is filled. For other areas (such as finished wood products and processed mineral goods), Bhutan 
must  invest  in  skill  and  technology  that  allow  growth  in  the  industries  while  respecting  the 
environmental needs of the country.  
 
 
 
The  performance  of  the  service  and  trade  sector3  has  been  impressive  in  recent  years. 
20. 
Much development has taken place in the tourism industry, with benefits spilling over to the service 
sector.  Sales  activities  in  the  hotels  and  restaurants  have  been  improving  over  the  years.  The 
sector  growth  increased  to  13.3%  in  2005,  as  compared  to  12.4%  in  the  previous  year.  It  is 
important to note that this sector represented almost 42% of the overall nominal GDP in 2005.  
 
21. 
Tourism.  Bhutanese  tourism  began  around  1974  and  is  a  sector  with  great  earning 
potential for the Bhutanese economy. Since its inception, the development of the tourism industry 
is  consistently  guided  by  the  country  policy  which  is  to  ensure  the  preservation  of  Bhutan's 
environment, traditional culture, and values. As a result, tourism development focuses on a high-
end market, with low numbers of high-paying tourists. Most importantly, it is the country’s desire to 
ensure that Bhutan’s unique and delicate cultural heritage is not overpowered by large numbers of 
visitors entering the country. Thus, facilities and services (hotels, airline services, and roads) have 
not yet had to cater to large numbers of tourists.  
 
In a span of almost three decades, tourist arrivals have risen from 287 in 1974 to 13,626 in 
22. 
2005.  The  tourism  sector  continues  to  be  recognized  as  a  priority  sector  with  immense  growth 
potential and as a major source of income for the Government. Tourism revenues have increased 
considerably,  from  $12.5  million  in  2004,  to  $18.5  million  in  2005,  and  $24  million  in  2006.  More 
importantly, the tourism sector is wholly run by the private sector, and, therefore, has significant job 
creation  implications  for  Bhutan's  growing  working  population.  Yet,  as  of  2005,  only  1.6%  of  the 
total labor force was engaged in the hotel and restaurant industry.

and private social, personal, and recreational services.

telecommunications  have  been 

23. 
Tourism is the largest source of convertible currency earnings. Tourism receipts consist of 
royalties and taxes collected from tour operators. In the high season, each tourist pays $200 per 
day, of which a 10% commission is given to the overseas agent and the rest goes to Bhutan. Out 
of  the  receipts  to  Bhutan  (i.e.,  $180),  35%  is  the  agreed  royalty  to  the  Government,  2%  is  the 
withheld tax to the Government, and each tour operator receives $111.40 per day.  
 
24. 
Constraints.  There  are  some  factors  that  could  affect  the  sustainability  of  the  tourism 
industry. Firstly, tourist arrivals in Bhutan are subject to pronounced seasonality. Around 70% of all 
international visitors arrive in the month of April and during September–November, which are the 
best months with regards to weather and are ideal for trekking, and religious and cultural festivals 
take  place  all  over  the  country  around  this  time.  At  other  times  of  the  year  there  is  little  activity, 
especially  during  January–February  and  June–July.  Consequently,  there  is  a  significant  shortage 
of facilities during the peak seasons and a lack of business in the low seasons. Secondly, tourist 
destinations are limited due to the limited transport access to different parts of the country. Tourism 
in  Bhutan  is  still  densely  concentrated  in  the  districts  of  Paro,  Thimphu,  Punakha,  and 
Wangdiphodrang.  Few  tourists  manage  to  visit  parts  of  the  central  valleys  such  as  Trongsa  and 
Bumthang. The current average length of stay is 6 days, with the entry point to the country in the 
west. Therefore, the objective of developing tourism throughout the country is yet to be achieved.  
 
25. 
Thirdly, there are a number of infrastructural impediments to increasing the capacity of the 
tourism  industry.  Due  to  the  country’s  difficult  terrain,  roads  are  difficult  and  time-consuming  to 
build, maintain, and upgrade. Bhutan’s high altitude also does not allow night flights or alternative 
transport  in  case  of  foggy  and  rainy  weather.  There  is  only  one  airport  open  for  day  flights. 
Recently, 
internet  bookings  and 
communication  should  be  further  facilitated.  Other  areas  to  be  further  improved  for  tourism 
development  include  the  supporting  infrastructure  of  tourism,  such  as  better  local  transport  and 
more or better banking services, including automatic teller machines connecting to overseas banks 
and greater acceptance of credit cards. 
 
26. 
Target  Industries  and  Products  with  Growth  Potential.  The  tourism  sector  could  grow 
even further with the introduction of the following initiatives to address the above constraints. First, 
to  reduce  seasonality,  the  country  needs  to  attract  new  clients  who  usually  travel  through  South 
Asia and Southeast Asia during Bhutan’s low season. Opening new entry and exit points through 
Samdrup, Jongkhar, and Gelephu would lead to the spread of tourism benefits to the central and 
eastern region. In addition, other potential tourism products include new trekking routes (such as 
access  to  Merak  and  Sakten  in  eastern  Bhutan)  and  new  products  such  as  white-water  rafting, 
elephant treks, paragliding, mountain biking, and wildlife and bird watching. Manas and Zhemgang 
(Tingtibi) are other areas with enormous potential for specialized tours for bird and orchid lovers. 
Opening  up  these  areas  would  help  overcome  problems  with  seasonality  and  add  more  value  to 
the industry, and would also spread benefits to the existing tourism areas.  
 
27. 
Niche-market travelers usually have broad travel experience and high levels of education, 
and  therefore  high  levels  of  expectation.  To  maintain  good  service  to  the  target  groups, 
professional levels of services, ranging from basic sanitation and hygiene in hotels to preparation 
of  food,  should  be  further  enhanced.  Other  long-term  improvements  should  include  air  access, 
roads, and other transport services. The Government could also allocate part of the royalty earned 
through tourism to further market and develop Bhutan’s image and profile by promoting branding, 
off-season marketing, introducing traditional medicine, and promoting neighboring-country visits in 
tour packages.

Appendix 6 

BHUTAN DEVELOPMENT FINANCE CORPORATION DUE DILIGENCE 
 

1. 
Establishment and Its Social Mandate. The Bhutan Development Finance Corporation 
(BDFC) was formed as a development organization on 31 January 1988 under a Royal Charter 
with  assistance  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  equity  participation  of  the 
Government  and  other  financial  institutions.  As  the  only  development  finance  institution  in 
Bhutan,  BDFC  is  mandated  to  provide  credit  to  both  small  and  medium-sized  industrial  and 
agricultural  activities  in  Bhutan,  especially  in  rural  areas.  Subsequently,  in  December  1990, 
BDFC  was  registered  as  a  company  under  the  Companies  Act  (2000)  and  as  a  financial 
institution under the Financial Institutions Act (1992). 
 
2. 
Capital Structure and Sources of Funding. BDFC has an authorized capital stock of 
Nu200  million.  The  paid-up  capital  is  Nu100  million,  of  which  the  Government  holds  87%,  the 
Bank  of  Bhutan  (BOB)  7.5%,  the  Royal  Insurance  Corporation  of  Bhutan  3%  and  the  Bhutan 
National  Bank  (BNB)  2.5%.  Since  the  Government  owns  the  majority  of  shares,  BDFC  is 
classified  as  a  government-owned  corporation.  As  a  nonbank  financial  institution,  BDFC  does 
not have direct access to the domestic savings market (other than for existing group borrowing 
customers).  Since  incorporation,  BDFC  has  thus  been  the  recipient  of  both  loans  and  grant 
funding  from  various  donors  such  as  ADB,  the  Kuwait  Fund  for  Arabic  and  Economic 
Development, and the International Fund for Agricultural Development as well as grant funding 
from  the  Government.  BDFC  also  has  raised  some  long-term  funds  locally  from  the  National 
Pension and Provident Fund, BNB, and BOB, using some of the excess liquidity of the financial 
sector. However, BDFC’s loan portfolio growth projections for the next 5 years already exceed 
the  organization’s  current  funding  resources.  Therefore,  there  is  a  need  to  raise  additional 
funding  and  improve  lending  to  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSME), 
particularly the small entrepreneurs. 
 
3. 
Capital  Adequacy  and  Liquidity  Requirements.  The  minimum  capital  requirement  is 
8%  of  risk-weighted  assets  for  all  financial  institutions,  according  to  the  Royal  Monetary 
Authority’s  (RMA’s)  Prudential  Regulations  (2002).  BDFC’s  risk-based  capital  ratio  was 
calculated  at  42%  in  2006.  The  astonishingly  high  ratio  was  due  to  the  fact  that,  as  a 
nondepository  financial  institution,  BDFC’s  equity  was  mostly  sourced  from  grants,  reserves, 
and  retained  earnings,  which  were  well  above  the  minimum  requirement.  In  addition,  as  a 
nonbank financial institution, BDFC was required to maintain a minimum 10% of total liabilities 
as  liquidity.  As  of  the  end  of  2006,  BDFC’s  liquidity  ratio  was  13.9%,  exceeding  the  statutory 
liquidity requirement by a small margin. 
 
4. 
Composition  of  Directorate  and  Management.  To  date,  BDFC  has  not  been  able  to 
diversify  its  ownership.  The  board  of  directors,  chaired  by  the  secretary  of  Finance,  has 
remained dominated by the Government which is exercising its governance over BDFC through 
different  ministries  (Ministry  of  Finance,  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry,  and  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture). The management structure consists of the managing director, who is appointed by 
the Government, and four general managers, who are responsible for finance, credit operations, 
branch  operations,  and  central  support.  BDFC’s  corporate  governance  structure  and  policies 
and  risk  management  functions  are  not  adequate  compared  to  existing  volumes,  portfolio 
structure, and best banking practices. Therefore, the ongoing TA1 will assist BDFC’s board and 
senior  management  to  adequately  execute  their  oversight  function.  In  addition,  the  recently

Financing Component. Manila (TA 4837-BHU approved on 11 September). 

 

 Appendix 6 

61 

approved Financial Sector Development Program (FSDP)2 has measures to improve corporate 
governance  in  the  financial  sector  as  a  whole.  It  will  enable  RMA  to  enforce  corporate 
governance of all financial institutions via processes such as an appropriate board structure with 
a  minimum  of  50%  participation  from  the  private  sector,  and  the  implementation  of  a  fit-and-
proper test for the board of directors.  
 
5. 
Corporate Strategy and Business Plan. In 2003, BDFC revised its strategy with ADB 
assistance,3  and  developed  its  Five-Year  Business  Plan  (2003–2007).  A  detailed  operational 
plan was developed for the first 12 months to guide BDFC’s management in the implementation 
of  the  new  strategy.  However,  due  to  the  shortage  of  management  skills  and  staff  (as  BDFC 
kept  losing  staff  due  to  high  turnover)  and  in  the  absence  of  any  further  external  assistance, 
BDFC  was  not  able  to  follow  through  with  the  implementation  of  the  recommended  business 
plan. The human-resource deficit and quality improvements are to be addressed in the ongoing 
TA 4837 (footnote 1) which, in consultation with management and staff of BDFC, will formulate 
a  human-resource  development  strategy  in  parallel  with  the  business plan  in  order  to  develop 
the MSME sector. 4 
 
6. 
Branch  Network  and Rural  Outreach.  BDFC  currently  has  a  head  office  in  Thimphu, 
three regional offices (one each in the western, central, and eastern regions), 22 branches (one 
in every dzongkhag [district], except in two large dzongkhags which each have two branches), 
and a mobile banking facility operational in 120 gewogs (blocks). The western region has nine 
branches,  the  eastern  region  has  seven  branches,  and  the  central  region  six  branches.  The 
countrywide  distribution  network  makes  BDFC  accessible  to  most  people,  including  those  in 
rural areas, on a regular basis, and capable to service the majority of the rural communities in 
Bhutan.5 As of December 2006, BDFC had 16,000 active clients in rural areas, or 18.6% of total 
rural  households.  However,  the  operational  costs  of  the  rural  lending  operations  are  relatively 
high compared with its revenues.  
 
Human Resources. At the end of 2006, BDFC had 171 employees, of which 54 work at 
7. 
the  head  office.  Staff  turnover  has  constantly  been  high  during  the  past  5  years,  the  principal 
reasons  being  the  comparatively  low  salary  levels  at  BDFC  compared  to  other  financial 
institutions, and staff being released subsequent to fraud cases at branch level. Because of high 
staff  turnover  and  underinvestment  in  human  resources  and  skills  development,  many  staff 
members lack experience, and many loan officers do not have the appropriate skills for a proper 
project  appraisal.  BDFC  needs  to  aggressively  address  this  issue  through  a  thorough  and 
standardized  training  curriculum  for  loan  officers.  A  human-resource  department  division  was 
established  in  2003  to  obtain  and  secure  sufficient  staff  through  adequate  human-resource 
management; however, the division currently has only limited authority. The division is primarily 
providing administrative support, while all decisions related to human resources and training are 
still  made  by  the  management  committee.  Therefore,  in  view  of  the  need  for  a  better  human-
resource system, the ongoing TA 4837 (footnote 1) will provide consultancy and relevant skills 
training to address the issues of human resources and skills development.

8. 
Financial Performance. The operating income from 2001  to 2006 has shown a 146% 
growth  from  Nu78.1  million  to  Nu191.8  million.  The  net  profit  before  tax  has  shown  a  similar 
trend, increasing from Nu24.0 million in 2001 to Nu88.2 million in 2006, a growth of 267%. The 
net margin has improved from 31% in 2001 to 46% in 2006. The net profit referred to above is 
arrived  at  after  providing  for  provisions  and  write-offs  amounting  to  Nu92.9  million  during  the 
period under review. No dividends have been declared during the lifetime of BDFC (see tables 
A6.1  and  A6.2  for  more  financial  data  of  BDFC  for  the  years  ending  31  December  2001  to 
2006.) 
 
9. 
Operating expenses as a percentage of revenue have been decreasing. The figure was 
in the 30–35% range up to 2002, since when it has been in the 25–30% range, and was 27% in 
2006. Return on equity has also been increasing, from 7% in 2001 to 13.1% in 2006. Return on 
assets  was  6.2%,  which  was  marginally  below  the  rate  of  6.8%  achieved  last  year,  but  both 
were significantly better than the industry average. The declined return on equity figure is largely 
due to the poor performance of BDFC’s branch offices.  
 
10. 
BDFC  now  prepares  separate  accounts,  including  a  balance  sheet,  for  the  branch 
offices. The total equity of BDFC has been split up between the branches and the head office on 
the basis of the source of donations and the purpose for which such donation was given. On this 
basis,  the  return  on  equity  from  branch  operations  was  only  6.1%  compared  to  a  return  of 
20.7% on head office operations.  
 
11. 
Loan  Portfolio  Analysis.  BDFC  has  witnessed  remarkable  loan  portfolio  growth  over 
the last 5 years, with an average annual growth rate of 20.5% between 2001 and 2006. In 2006, 
total  outstanding  loans  (principal)  grew  by  19.6%.  This  evolution  comprises  a  growth  in  the 
number of active borrowers (17,667 as of December 2006); however, compared to 2005, there 
has  been  a  slight  decrease  in  average  disbursed  loan  size  per  client  for  loans  of  up  to  Nu5 
million  (classified  as  MSME  loans).  BDFC  currently  has  loans  exceeding  Nu1.0  million  on  an 
average in the manufacturing, mining, and tourism sectors. Only 94 (or 0.6%) of BDFC’s clients 
have received loans exceeding Nu2 million, and out of these 26% were for housing and mining. 
The  average  maturity  of  the  BDFC  loan  portfolio  is  currently  3.16  years  and  only  10%  of  the 
borrowers have received a loan with a maturity exceeding 5 years. Concentration is low in the 
overall  loan  portfolio,  with  the  top  10  borrowers  representing  19.7%  of  the  total  portfolio.  The 
largest  customer  exposure  accounted  for  11.3%  of  equity  and  5.5%  of  loans;  this  was  to  a 
leading consortium of companies in the manufacturing and service sector. 
 
12. 
BDFC  makes  provisions  for  loan  losses  as  stipulated  in  the  Prudential  Regulations 
(2002)  given  by  RMA.  Based  on  the  guidelines  and  definition  of  90  days  overdue  as 
nonperforming  loans  (NPL),  the  NPL  ratios  as  percentage  of  total  loans  have  improved 
significantly  since  1998.  The  NPL  ratio  declined  from  36%  in  1998  to  18.7%  in  2002,6  and 
further to 15% in 2006. However, the highest NPL ratios are in the agriculture (31% in 2005 and 
32% in 2006) and service industry sectors (16% in 2005 and 17% in 2006). In addition, the NPL 
ratio for BDFC branch operations (24% in 2005 and 25% in 2006) is higher than that of the head 
office  (16.6%  for  2005  and  13.7%  for  2006).  The  unsatisfactory  portfolio  quality  at  the  branch 
and sector levels indicates insufficient capacity at the branch levels as well as a need to further

strengthen lending skills, including risk assessment, for target sectoral clients. The ongoing TA 
4837  (footnote  1)  will  therefore  assist  BDFC  in  enhancing  its  institutional  capacity  in  MSME 
lending skills as well as in developing suitable services and products to meet the needs of target 
sector clients. 

Scope  of  Lending  Operations.  BDFC’s  scope  of  operations 

13. 
The  current  loan  loss  provisioning  policy  used  by  BDFC  is  in  compliance  with  the 
Prudential  Regulations  (2002).  The  loan  loss  is  100%  fully  provided.  However,  the  current 
Prudential  Regulations  have  a  lenient  timeframe  for  substandard  loan  classifications.  For 
example,  substandard  loans  can  go  for  as  long  as  12  months  before  being  classified  as 
doubtful. Doubtful loans are declared as loss after 24 months. Loan loss provisions that would 
have  been  written  off  after  12  months  using  international  standards  remain  on  the  books 
indefinitely. This is because financial institutions are not able to write the loan loss provisions off 
due to a lack of a write-off policy in the country, as well as the difficulty faced in obtaining the 
court orders needed to write off bad loans. While the ongoing FSDP is addressing the issue of 
loan classification in conformity with international best practice, there is also a need for BDFC to 
develop  a  write-off  policy7  to  recognize  the  bad  loans  that  have  been  overdue  for  a  very  long 
time.  Some  loans  are  delinquent  more  than  10  years  in  the  book.  Specifically,  in  view  of  the 
recent improvement of BDFC’s portfolio, it reveals that most of the existing NPLs in the book are 
those  long-standing  NPLs  and  thereby  do  not  reflect  the  accurate  value  of  the  institution's 
assets.  In  this  regard,  the  ongoing  TA  4837  (footnote  1)  will  assist  BDFC  in  developing  an 
adequate write-off policy to resolve the issue of long-standing, accumulated NPLs in addition to 
providing institutional capacity building. 
 
14. 
loans, 
investments,  financial  services,  and  project  development.  BDFC  provides  term  loans  with 
differing maximum maturities depending on sector (e.g., up to 10 years for manufacturing sector 
and up to 5 years for handicraft or cottage sectors); the average term is 3.16 years. According 
to BDFC’s loan classification, as outlined in BDFC’s credit manual, the maximum loan amount 
for micro enterprises is Nu50,000 and for small enterprises Nu1 million, whereas medium-sized 
enterprise  loans  will  not  exceed  Nu5  million.  Loans  are  primarily  approved  on  the  basis  of 
collateral  rather  than  on  character  assessment  and  cash  flow  analysis,  due  to  the  lack  of 
appropriate  project  appraisal  skills  among  loan  officers.  There  is  no  formal  policy  for  offering 
differential interest rates based on the client’s credit rating or term, but for type of loans. Interest 
rates are between 12 and 16%, with the exception of group lending where the rate is 10%. 
 
15. 
Project  Appraisal  and  Monitoring.  Many  procedures  and  policies,  including  credit 
operating  procedures,  reporting  requirements,  and  formats  are  outlined  in  BDFC’s  credit 
manual.  Nevertheless,  formalization  and  application  of  these  procedures  remain  areas  of 
weakness and the guidelines for project analysis lack detail and do not appear to be rigorously 
applied. Whereas BDFC’s credit appraisal process entails greater scrutiny for larger loans, the 
analysis  of  smaller  loans  is  mainly  reduced  to  the  valuation  of  collateral.  The  loan  approval 
process  is  decentralized  with  a  hierarchical  scale  of  delegated  authority  and  approval  limits 
stipulated by the credit committee or the board of directors.8 BDFC’s loan processing time from 
receipt of application to approval ranges from 1 week to 4 months, depending on the loan size 
and response of the sponsors.

Appendix 6 

Loan Eligibility Criteria. Detailed guidelines on borrower and project eligibility are laid 
16. 
out in the credit manual. In general, projects that show business viability and generate adequate 
returns  to  repay  the  loan  are  eligible  for  financing.  A  debt-equity  ratio  of  not  more  than  75:25 
and  adequate  collateral  of  1.0–1.5  times  to  cover  the  loan  amount  is  requested.  In  addition, 
when  appraising  new  loans  for  new  projects  or  companies  which  affect  the  environmental 
factors  reviewed  by  the  National  Environmental  Committee,  BDFC  requires  a  copy  of  the 
certificate  before  the  credit  approval  is  made.  There  is  no  internally  developed  environmental 
due-diligence  procedure;  however,  the  system  of  requiring  certificates  from  the  National 
Environmental Committee ensures a minimum environmental standard for new projects. 
 
17. 
Accounting  and  Compliance  with  Statutory  Requirements.  Overall,  BDFC  follows 
accounting  standards  consistent  with  the  requirements  for  the  banking  industry  and  is  in 
compliance with the RMA statutory and regulatory requirements.9 BDFC has a well functioning 
and  reliable  accounting  system  that  produces  detailed  reports  at  both  the  consolidated  and 
branch level. The chief financing officer and finance team have strong accounting skills and are 
knowledgeable in financial analysis. BDFC has its accounts and financial statements, including 
balance  sheet,  income  statement,  cash  flow  statement,  and  other  related  statements,  audited 
annually in accordance with sound auditing standards by an independent external auditor10 from 
India. An internal audit unit has been set up at head office to ensure proper management of the 
systems, and guard against misuse and irregularities. As of November 2006, an internal auditor 
has  been  assigned  to  each  of  the  three  regional  offices  to  guard  against  further  misuse  and 
manage the fraud cases at branch level.  
 
18.  Management Information System. BDFC is in the process of converting from its micro 
banker  system  to  an  internet-based  banking  system  with  SQL  Server  2000.11  This  is  being 
developed in conjunction with a Dhaka based software company (Southtech Limited) and BDFC 
is  aiming  for  a  complete  conversion  to  the  new  system  (including  all  branches)  by  the  end  of 
2007.  At  present,  the  branches  send  data  updates  on  a  monthly  basis  to  the  head  office  by 
email,  from  which  data  is  imported  into  the  head  office  system.  It  is  expected  that  the  new 
software will be able to accommodate the needs of BDFC’s internal reporting and management 
information system requirements.

ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FRAMEWORK 
 

Introduction 

A. 
 
The proposed Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Sector Development Program 
1. 
(MSME  SDP)  is  designed  to  promote  a  vibrant  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprise 
(MSME) sector and encourage private sector development for sustainable economic growth. To 
achieve  this  goal,  the  MSME  SDP  contains  credit  line  assistance  of  $5  million  to  increase 
access to finance for MSMEs, particularly in rural areas. 
 
2. 
The  only  financial  institution  participating  in  the  credit  facility  is  BDFC.  The  proposed 
credit  line  aims  to  support  financing  of  an  estimated  1,400  additional  MSMEs  entering  the 
market  between  2008  and  2010.  The  grant  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  new  loans 
advanced  by  BDFC  and  will  not  be  used  to  refinance  the  portfolio  of  old  loans  or  add  to  the 
existing portfolio of BDFC. The maximum size of subloans for individual borrowers will be Nu2 
million (about $49,000), with a grace period of up to 1 year and a maximum maturity of 5 years. 
Based  on  historical  figures,  the  average  MSME  loan  size  in  BDFC  is  Nu760,000  (about 
$18,700) with an average maturity of 3 years. 
 
3. 
Despite the fact that the size of the onlending funded through the credit line is relatively 
small  and  has  insignificant  environmental  impacts,  a  basic  review  of  the  environmental 
management  system  framework  of  the  country  as  well  as  BDFC  (including  the  review 
procedures of subprojects) is provided as follows.  
 
B. 
 
4. 
The  Government  of  Bhutan  (the  Government)  has  implemented  very  stringent 
environmental  rules  and  regulations  since  1990.  The  principle  of  environmentally  sustainable 
development was included in the national environmental strategy as well as the country midterm 
development  plan  (i.e.,  various  5-year  plans).  As  a  result,  the  Government  prepared  and 
enacted  the  Environmental  Assessment  Act  in  2000,  and  further  adopted  the  Regulations  for 
Environmental  Clearance  of  Projects  (2002)  and  Regulations  for  Strategic  Environmental 
Assessment  (2002).  Subsequently,  10  guidelines  were  issued  and  implemented  to  provide 
sectoral instructions for environmental compliance in the areas and/or sectors of (i) environment 
discharge standard, (ii) forestry, (iii) mines, (iv)  tourism, (v)  highways and roads, (vi) industrial 
projects, (vii) overhead utilities, (viii) storm-water drainage system, (ix)  electricity transmission, 
and (x) urban development. It is worth mentioning that the preparation of the abovementioned 
environmental legislation and relevant regulations were supported by the technical assistance of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).1  ADB’s  technical  assistance  also  included  training  to 
strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  of  the  government  agencies  responsible  for  implementing 
environmental assessment and clearance procedures. It is noted that the current environmental 
management  system  (EMS)  in  Bhutan  meets  international  standards  and  closely  follows  a 
format provided by ADB.

C. 

Environmental Assessment and Clearance Procedures 

from 

issuance  of  environmental  clearance  certificates 

In Bhutan, the main framework for environmental protection and assessment is a system 
5. 
of 
the  National  Environmental 
Commission (NEC). The NEC was established under the Environmental Assessment Act, and is 
authorized  to  issue  environmental  clearance  certificates  in  all  sectors,  except  for  smaller 
projects and sector-specific projects, in which case NEC authorizes the competent authorities to 
issue environmental clearance for projects in their respective sectors.  
 
6. 
Under  the  Environmental  Assessment  Act,  any  project  or  any  person  is  required  to 
conduct environmental assessment and obtain environmental clearance before starting up. That 
is, all enterprises need to submit satisfactory environmental assessment documents in order to 
obtain  government  environmental  clearance  for  business  formalization.  The  issuance  of  an 
environmental  clearance  is  also  a  prerequisite,  regardless  of  whether  the  issuance  of  the 
development  consent  (e.g.,  license,  lease,  or  permit  for  land  use,  construction,  or  business 
operation) is needed. Environmental clearance is required at all stages of business operations. 
In addition, the environmental clearance certificate needs to be renewed at least every 5 years, 
unless  a  shorter  period  is  stated  in  the  environmental  clearance.  Considering  the  stringent 
environmental policy, rules, and regulations, the current practice of all financial institutions when 
granting  new  loans  for projects  or companies  is  to  acquire  a  copy  of  the  certificate  before  the 
credit  approval  is  made.  As  such,  the  current  procedure  followed  by  the  financial  institutions, 
including  BDFC,  is  implicitly  in  accordance  with  the  country  system,  even  though  there  is  no 
internal  environmental  due-diligence  procedure.  Additionally,  the  current  system  of  requiring 
certificates from NEC ensures a minimum environmental standard applies to new projects.

Poverty Analysis 

Targeting Classification: General intervention 

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan:  
According  to  the  Government’s  Bhutan  Vision  2020  and  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan  (2002–2007),1  private  sector 
development—especially the growth of micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs)—is regarded as a key to 
promoting  more  equitable  distribution  of  wealth  (both  socially  and  regionally),  sustainable  economic  growth,  and 
overall poverty reduction. Private sector development, with an emphasis on rural-based, micro, and small enterprises, 
will  specifically  contribute  to  (i)  new  employment  generation,  especially  off-farm  employment  opportunities  in  rural 
areas, and reduction of rural-urban migration; and (ii) absorbing the increased labor force due to the increase in the 
number of new graduates entering the job market. The Ninth Five-Year Plan estimates that, between 2005 and 2010, 
approximately 69,000 persons will enter the labor market, posing a challenge to the Government to urgently address 
the employment issue, a situation aggravated by diminishing employment opportunities in the public sector and limited 
labor  productivity  in  the  traditional  agriculture  sector.  Therefore,  support  to  the  private  sector,  particularly  MSMEs  in 
agro-processing, food production, manufacturing, tourism, and nonfarm rural economic activities, becomes one of the 
Government’s strategic focuses for further fostering economic growth and promoting equitable income distribution. 
 
There are various development bottlenecks in the private and/or MSME sector, including a lack of enabling business 
environment, limited access to credit, deficient business development services (BDS), and an inadequate supporting 
infrastructure. The MSME Sector Development Program (MSME SDP) therefore will provide support to strengthen the 
policy  and  regulatory  environment  for  doing  business,  improve  access  to  credit,  provide  business  support  services, 
and enhance capacity building to help overcome constraints to private sector development. It is envisaged that gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth contributed by the private sector (measured by the share of GDP contributed by the 
manufacturing, trade, and service-related sectors) will increase from 49% in 2005.2 
 
B. 
The  MSME  SDP  is  expected  to  foster  an  enabling  policy  and  regulatory  environment,  eliminate  structural  barriers 
constraining small enterprises’ access to key resources, including credit and nonfinancial BDS, support private sector 
BDS  providers  market  entrance,  and  provide  capacity  building  to  stakeholders  for  smooth  project  and  program 
implementation.  The  MSME  SDP  is  essential  for  successful  development  of  the  MSME  sector  and  cannot  be 
implemented as stand-alone measures. The outcomes and expected economic and social impacts of the program as a 
whole which contribute to poverty reduction are as follows. 
 
Enabling  Policy  and  Regulatory  Environment.  Policy  actions  proposed  for  developing  an  enabling  policy  and 
regulatory  environment  for  MSMEs  include  establishing  a  coordinated  policy  and  institutional  framework  for  MSME 
development, and enhancing public governance and business regulations. These measures are expected to improve 
targeted policies and programs, availability of comprehensive information for MSMEs, and heighten public awareness 
of  the  MSME  sector.  Cost  for  accessing  such  information  on  business  regulations,  and  programs  and  services 
available to MSMEs, will be set at a minimum for the private sector, and also will be affordable to the poor. In addition, 
a  simple  and  transparent  regulatory  regime  will  reduce  the  costs  for  self  employment,  establishing  businesses,  and 
complying with statutory rules and regulations, and in turn help accelerate the growth of the MSME sector and create 
new employment opportunities, including for the poor. The proposed policy actions will also support good governance 
and further promote sustainable growth for overall poverty reduction. 
 
Improved Access to Finance. The proposed program measures for increasing MSMEs’ access to finance include (i) 
provision  of  a  credit  line  to  meet  the  shortage  of  funds  available  to  MSMEs;  and  (ii)  strengthening  of  institutional 
capacity of the Bhutan Development Finance Corporation (BDFC) to enable effective channeling of funds to MSMEs. 
The  two  components  thereby  are  expected  to  stimulate  growth  within  the  private  MSME  sector  in  Bhutan,  and  the 
extension  of the credit line to rural areas is  expected to  help ease regional and economic inequalities.  Furthermore, 
enhanced  institutional  capability  of  BDFC  and  the  introduction  of  cash-flow  based  lending  will  reduce  collateral 
requirements  which  can  significantly  improve  access  to  financial  services  to  MSMEs  and  also  reduce  transaction 
costs, making financial services affordable for the poor.  
 
Enhanced  Competitiveness  of  Bhutanese  MSMEs  through  Access  to  Qualified  BDS.  Proposed  program  policy 
actions  and  project  components  for  enhancing  competitiveness  of  Bhutanese  MSMEs  through  strengthened  BDS 
include (i) the establishment of a cost-sharing facility (CSF), and (ii) improving quality control and product standards. 

                                                 
1  The Ninth Five-Year Plan has been extended by 1 year to cover the period 2002–2008. 
2  The data is the most recent available from the Royal Monetary Authority. Annual Report of Royal Monetary Authority 

2005/6. Thimphu. 

 

 Appendix 10 

75 

The CSF aims to improve demand-driven access to BDS for MSMEs in order to increase their technical capacity and 
operational efficiency and further prevent increases in unemployment which may end in social unrest and increasing 
poverty. The cost-sharing scheme will allow micro and small enterprises to obtain access to key resources, including 
market information and technology, to develop and/or expand their businesses and therefore generate more income 
and employment opportunities, including for the poor.  
 
Given the current limitations on data collection, especially in the MSME sector, quantifying the potential impact of the 
proposed  Program  on  the  poor  or  the  sector  is  extremely  difficult.  Therefore,  the  Program  will  closely  monitor 
outcomes and collect program and project data and information throughout implementation to ensure that there is no 
adverse impact on poor and vulnerable groups.

C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?  
Discussions  will  be  held  with  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  Royal  Monetary  Authority,  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry, 
Ministry of Agriculture, BDFC, and other stakeholders, including multilateral and bilateral organizations, such as the 
United  Nations  Development  Programme  and  the  Netherlands  Development  Organization.  These  will  ensure  the 
participation of stakeholders in proposing quality action plans and recommendations. 
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
The implementation of the MSME SDP will be based on public-private collaborative processes. An MSME division, to 
be established and mandated to coordinate and implement the MSME SDP, will consist of representatives from the 
concerned  ministries,  industry  associations,  and  the  private  sector.  Capacity  building  will  be  integrated  into  the 
program and provided to key stakeholders. 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy  to  maximize  impacts  on  women:  None.  However,  the  Program  will  improve  knowledge  about  female 
entrepreneurship and its socioeconomic role. Knowledge regarding constraints of businesses owned by  women  will 
be  improved  by  proposed  policy  reforms,  enhanced  MSME  financing  through  BDFC,  and  better  business 
development services.
